{"uri": "2024-05-371794187", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-29", "time": "08:36:03", "dateTime": "2024-05-29T08:36:03Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-29T08:30:14Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.9764705896377563, "url": "https://www.rfi.fr/en/international-news/20240529-us-china-defence-chiefs-to-hold-rare-talks-in-singapore", "title": "US, China defence chiefs to hold rare talks in Singapore", "body": "Singapore (AFP) - The US and Chinese defence chiefs are set to hold rare direct talks in Singapore this weekend, offering hopes of further military dialogue aimed at preventing flashpoint disputes from spinning out of control.\n\nThe expected meeting between the United States' Lloyd Austin and China's Dong Jun at the Shangri-La Dialogue will be the first substantive face-to-face talks between their countries' defence chiefs in 18 months.\n\nThe security forum is an annual gathering of defence chiefs from around the world that has in recent years become a barometer of US-China relations.\n\nThis year's edition, starting Friday, will come a week after China held military drills around Taiwan and warned of war over the island.\n\nThe dispute over democratic and US-backed Taiwan, which China has vowed to bring under its control, is the highest-profile of many rows between the global powers.\n\nBeijing is also furious over Washington's deepening defence ties in the Asia-Pacific, particularly with the Philippines.\n\nChina has in recent years grown increasingly assertive in staking its claims in the contested South China Sea, including by building artificial islands and militarising them.\n\nIt effectively suspended military talks with the United States in late 2022 in response to then-US House Speaker Nancy Pelosi's visit to Taiwan.\n\nThe two sides agreed after a summit between Chinese leader Xi Jinping and US President Joe Biden in November last year to restart high-level military talks.\n\nAustin and Dong then talked over the phone in April.\n\nTheir meeting in Singapore -- announced by the Pentagon last week -- would be the most substantial encounter on defence since the presidential summit.\n\nHowever, the two sides have yet to resume much of the direct military dialogue that was scrapped after Pelosi's Taiwan visit.\n\n\"The hope here is for the (Dong-Austin) meeting to be the beginnings of cautious rapprochement to re-establish military-to-military open lines of communication,\" Mustafa Izzuddin, senior international affairs analyst with consultancy Solaris Strategies Singapore, told AFP.\n\nBiden and Xi agreed at their summit to set up a communications channel between the US Indo-Pacific Command chief and China's commanders responsible for military operations near Taiwan, Japan and in the South China Sea.\n\nA US official recently highlighted the importance of direct talks between those commanders.\n\nIzzuddin described such dialogue as \"essential\".\n\n\"It's exceptionally important because when we talk about what is happening in the South China Sea and Taiwan, it's essentially about defence and security,\" he said.\n\n- Threat of conflict -\n\nAustin and Dong will also give speeches this weekend at the Shangri-La Dialogue in which they are expected to touch on a range of their nations' pressure points.\n\nThe United States is increasingly worried about China's fast-developing military capabilities.\n\nChina already has the largest navy in the world and this month carried out a sea test of its third and biggest aircraft carrier.\n\nIn 2021, China reportedly stunned US defence officials with a globe-circling hypersonic test flight involving a high-speed missile launch over the South China Sea.\n\nIn Beijing, China's leaders are enraged by the United States routinely deploying warships and fighter jets in the Taiwan Strait and South China Sea.\n\nChina views this as part of a decades-long US effort to contain it.\n\n\"If the United States does not hit the brakes but continues to speed down the wrong path, no amount of guardrails can prevent derailing, and there will surely be conflict and confrontation,\" China's then-foreign minister Qin Gang said last year.\n\nSong Zhongping, a Chinese military analyst and former People's Liberation Army officer, told AFP that Dong's Singapore speech would likely include a call for the United States to stop \"provoking\" China on Taiwan and the South China Sea.\n\n\"We especially want to warn certain countries from outside the region -- the US, Japan -- that interfering in the Taiwan Strait and the South China Sea will inevitably cause serious regional conflict,\" he said.\n\nSong also downplayed the prospects of deeper US-China military dialogue unless the United States cut its support for Taiwan.\n\n\"If the US cannot turn a new leaf on this issue, it cannot achieve results no matter who it speaks with.\"", "source": {"uri": "rfi.fr", "dataType": "news", "title": "RFI"}, "authors": [], "news", "sim": 0.9607843160629272, "url": "https://www.ibtimes.com/us-china-defence-chiefs-hold-rare-talks-singapore-3733116", "title": "US, China Defence Chiefs To Hold Rare Talks In Singapore", "body": "The US and Chinese defence chiefs are set to hold rare direct talks in Singapore this weekend, offering hopes of further military dialogue aimed at preventing flashpoint disputes from spinning out of control.\n\nThe expected meeting between the United States' Lloyd Austin and China's Dong Jun at the Shangri-La Dialogue will be the first substantive face-to-face talks between their countries' defence chiefs in 18 months.\n\nThe security forum is an annual gathering of defence chiefs from around the world that has in recent years become a barometer of US-China relations.\n\nThis year's edition, starting Friday, will come a week after China held military drills around Taiwan and warned of war over the island.\n\nThe dispute over democratic and US-backed Taiwan, which China has vowed to bring under its control, is the highest-profile of many rows between the global powers.\n\nBeijing is also furious over Washington's deepening defence ties in the Asia-Pacific, particularly with the Philippines.\n\nChina has in recent years grown increasingly assertive in staking its claims in the contested South China Sea, including by building artificial islands and militarising them.\n\nIt effectively suspended military talks with the United States in late 2022 in response to then-US House Speaker Nancy Pelosi's visit to Taiwan.\n\nThe two sides agreed after a summit between Chinese leader Xi Jinping and US President Joe Biden in November last year to restart high-level military talks.\n\nAustin and Dong then talked over the phone in April.\n\nTheir meeting in Singapore -- announced by the Pentagon last week -- would be the most substantial encounter on defence since the presidential summit.\n\nHowever, the two sides have yet to resume much of the direct military dialogue that was scrapped after Pelosi's Taiwan visit.\n\n\"The hope here is for the (Dong-Austin) meeting to be the beginnings of cautious rapprochement to re-establish military-to-military open lines of communication,\" Mustafa Izzuddin, senior international affairs analyst with consultancy Solaris Strategies Singapore, told AFP.\n\nBiden and Xi agreed at their summit to set up a communications channel between the US Indo-Pacific Command chief and China's commanders responsible for military operations near Taiwan, Japan and in the South China Sea.\n\nA US official recently highlighted the importance of direct talks between those commanders.\n\nIzzuddin described such dialogue as \"essential\".\n\n\"It's exceptionally important because when we talk about what is happening in the South China Sea and Taiwan, it's essentially about defence and security,\" he said.\n\nAustin and Dong will also give speeches this weekend at the Shangri-La Dialogue in which they are expected to touch on a range of their nations' pressure points.\n\nThe United States is increasingly worried about China's fast-developing military capabilities.\n\nChina already has the largest navy in the world and this month carried out a sea test of its third and biggest aircraft carrier.\n\nIn 2021, China reportedly stunned US defence officials with a globe-circling hypersonic test flight involving a high-speed missile launch over the South China Sea.\n\nIn Beijing, China's leaders are enraged by the United States routinely deploying warships and fighter jets in the Taiwan Strait and South China Sea.\n\nChina views this as part of a decades-long US effort to contain it.\n\n\"If the United States does not hit the brakes but continues to speed down the wrong path, no amount of guardrails can prevent derailing, and there will surely be conflict and confrontation,\" China's then-foreign minister Qin Gang said last year.\n\nSong Zhongping, a Chinese military analyst and former People's Liberation Army officer, told AFP that Dong's Singapore speech would likely include a call for the United States to stop \"provoking\" China on Taiwan and the South China Sea.\n\n\"We especially want to warn certain countries from outside the region -- the US, Japan -- that interfering in the Taiwan Strait and the South China Sea will inevitably cause serious regional conflict,\" he said.\n\nSong also downplayed the prospects of deeper US-China military dialogue unless the United States cut its support for Taiwan.\n\n\"If the US cannot turn a new leaf on this {"uri": "8151308999", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-29", "time": "09:30:05", "dateTime": "2024-05-29T09:30:05Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-29T09:29:37Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.95686274766922, "url": "https://www.reformer.com/news/national/us-china-defence-chiefs-to-hold-rare-talks-in-singapore/article_e09fbdf5-e52e-5a02-afa0-96f2607f9773.html", "title": "US, China defence chiefs to hold rare talks in Singapore", "body": "The US and Chinese defence chiefs are set to hold rare direct talks in Singapore this weekend, offering hopes of further military dialogue aimed at preventing flashpoint disputes from spinning out of control.\n\nThe expected meeting between the United States' Lloyd Austin and China's Dong Jun at the Shangri-La Dialogue will be the first substantive face-to-face talks between their countries' defence chiefs in 18 months.\n\nThe security forum is an annual gathering of defence chiefs from around the world that has in recent years become a barometer of US-China relations.\n\nThis year's edition, starting Friday, will come a week after China held military drills around Taiwan and warned of war over the island.\n\nThe dispute over democratic and US-backed Taiwan, which China has vowed to bring under its control, is the highest-profile of many rows between the global powers.\n\nBeijing is also furious over Washington's deepening defence ties in the Asia-Pacific, particularly with the Philippines.\n\nChina has in recent years grown increasingly assertive in staking its claims in the contested South China Sea, including by building artificial islands and militarising them.\n\nIt effectively suspended military talks with the United States in late 2022 in response to then-US House Speaker Nancy Pelosi's visit to Taiwan.\n\nThe two sides agreed after a summit between Chinese leader Xi Jinping and US President Joe Biden in November last year to restart high-level military talks.\n\nAustin and Dong then talked over the phone in April.\n\nTheir meeting in Singapore -- announced by the Pentagon last week -- would be the most substantial encounter on defence since the presidential summit.\n\nHowever, the two sides have yet to resume much of the direct military dialogue that was scrapped after Pelosi's Taiwan visit.\n\n\"The hope here is for the (Dong-Austin) meeting to be the beginnings of cautious rapprochement to re-establish military-to-military open lines of communication,\" Mustafa Izzuddin, senior international affairs analyst with consultancy Solaris Strategies Singapore, told AFP.\n\nBiden and Xi agreed at their summit to set up a communications channel between the US Indo-Pacific Command chief and China's commanders responsible for military operations near Taiwan, Japan and in the South China Sea.\n\nA US official recently highlighted the importance of direct talks between those commanders.\n\nMore from this section Indian election: the use of deepfake causes concerns 'Poor weather conditions' cancels remainder of Bethpage Air Show at Jones Beach Oleksandr Usyk 'makes request to boxing chiefs' with potential blow on cards after Tyson Fury win\n\nIzzuddin described such dialogue as \"essential\".\n\n\"It's exceptionally important because when we talk about what is happening in the South China Sea and Taiwan, it's essentially about defence and security,\" he said.\n\n- Threat of conflict -\n\nAustin and Dong will also give speeches this weekend at the Shangri-La Dialogue in which they are expected to touch on a range of their nations' pressure points.\n\nThe United States is increasingly worried about China's fast-developing military capabilities.\n\nChina already has the largest navy in the world and this month carried out a sea test of its third and biggest aircraft carrier.\n\nIn 2021, China reportedly stunned US defence officials with a globe-circling hypersonic test flight involving a high-speed missile launch over the South China Sea.\n\nIn Beijing, China's leaders are enraged by the United States routinely deploying warships and fighter jets in the Taiwan Strait and South China Sea.\n\nChina views this as part of a decades-long US effort to contain it.\n\n\"If the United States does not hit the brakes but continues to speed down the wrong path, no amount of guardrails can prevent derailing, and there will surely be conflict and confrontation,\" China's then-foreign minister Qin Gang said last year.\n\nSong Zhongping, a Chinese military analyst and former People's Liberation Army officer, told AFP that Dong's Singapore speech would likely include a call for the United States to stop \"provoking\" China on Taiwan and the South China Sea.\n\n\"We especially want to warn certain countries from outside the region -- the US, Japan -- that interfering in the Taiwan Strait and the South China Sea will inevitably cause serious regional conflict,\" he said.\n\nSong also downplayed the prospects of deeper US-China military dialogue unless the United States cut its support for Taiwan.\n\n\"If the US cannot turn a new leaf on this issue, it cannot achieve results no matter who it speaks with.\"\n\nburs-mba/amj/kma/pbt", "source": {"uri": "reformer.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Brattleboro Reformer"}, "authors": [{"uri": "martin_abbugao@reformer.com", "name": "Martin Abbugao", vowed to bring under its control, is the highest-profile of many rows between the global powers.\n\nBeijing is also furious over Washington's deepening defence ties in the Asia-Pacific, particularly with the Philippines.\n\nChina has in recent years grown increasingly assertive in staking its claims in the contested South China Sea, including by building artificial islands and militarising them.\n\nIt effectively suspended military talks with the United States in late 2022 in response to then-US House Speaker Nancy Pelosi's visit to Taiwan.\n\nThe two sides agreed after a summit between Chinese leader Xi Jinping and US President Joe Biden in November last year to restart high-level military talks.\n\nAustin and Dong then talked over the phone in April.\n\nTheir meeting in Singapore -- announced by the Pentagon last week -- would be the most substantial encounter on defence since the presidential summit.\n\nHowever, the two sides have yet to resume much of the direct military dialogue that was scrapped after Pelosi's Taiwan visit.\n\n\"The hope here is for the (Dong-Austin) meeting to be the beginnings of cautious rapprochement to re-establish military-to-military open lines of communication,\" Mustafa Izzuddin, senior international affairs analyst with consultancy Solaris Strategies Singapore, told AFP.\n\nBiden and Xi agreed at their summit to set up a communications channel between the US Indo-Pacific Command chief and China's commanders responsible for military operations near Taiwan, Japan and in the South China Sea.\n\nA US official recently highlighted the importance of direct talks between those commanders.\n\nIzzuddin described such dialogue as \"essential\".\n\n\"It's exceptionally important because when we talk about what is already has the largest navy in the world and this month carried out a sea test of its third and biggest aircraft carrier.\n\nIn 2021, China reportedly stunned US defence officials with a globe-circling hypersonic test flight involving a high-speed missile launch over the South China Sea.\n\nIn Beijing, China's leaders are enraged by the United States routinely deploying warships and fighter jets in the Taiwan Strait and South China Sea.\n\nChina views this as part of a decades-long US effort to contain it.\n\n\"If the United States does not hit the brakes but continues to speed {"uri": "2024-05-371909597", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-29", "time": "10:11:38", "dateTime": "2024-05-29T10:11:38Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-29T08:28:49Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.9450980424880981, "url": "https://www.kulr8.com/news/national/us-china-defence-chiefs-to-hold-rare-talks-in-singapore/article_744f6aca-bcf0-5988-9a83-f002a573ab0e.html", "title": "US, China defence chiefs to hold rare talks in Singapore", "body": "The US and Chinese defence chiefs are set to hold rare direct talks in Singapore this weekend, offering hopes of further military dialogue aimed at preventing flashpoint disputes from spinning out of control.\n\nThe expected meeting between the United States' Lloyd Austin and China's Dong Jun at the Shangri-La Dialogue will be the first substantive face-to-face talks between their countries' defence chiefs in 18 months.\n\nThe security forum is an annual gathering of defence chiefs from around the world that has in recent years become a barometer of US-China relations.\n\nThis year's edition, starting Friday, will come a week after China held military drills around Taiwan and warned of war over the island.\n\nThe dispute over democratic and US-backed Taiwan, which China has vowed to bring under its control, is the highest-profile of many rows between the global powers.\n\nBeijing is also furious over Washington's deepening defence ties in the Asia-Pacific, particularly with the Philippines.\n\nChina has in recent years grown increasingly assertive in staking its claims in the contested South China Sea, including by building artificial islands and militarising them.\n\nIt effectively suspended military talks with the United States in late 2022 in response to then-US House Speaker Nancy Pelosi's visit to Taiwan.\n\nThe two sides agreed after a summit between Chinese leader Xi Jinping and US President Joe Biden in November last year to restart high-level military talks.\n\nAustin and Dong then talked over the phone in April.\n\nTheir meeting in Singapore -- announced by the Pentagon last week -- would be the most substantial encounter on defence since the presidential summit.\n\nHowever, the two sides have yet to resume much of the direct military dialogue that was scrapped after Pelosi's Taiwan visit.\n\n\"The hope here is for the (Dong-Austin) meeting to be the beginnings of cautious rapprochement to re-establish military-to-military open lines of communication,\" Mustafa Izzuddin, senior international affairs analyst with consultancy Solaris Strategies Singapore, told AFP.\n\nBiden and Xi agreed at their summit to set up a communications channel between the US Indo-Pacific Command chief and China's commanders responsible for military operations near Taiwan, Japan and in the South China Sea.\n\nA US official recently highlighted the importance of direct talks between those commanders.\n\nIzzuddin described such dialogue as \"essential\".\n\n\"It's exceptionally important because when we talk about what is happening in the South China Sea and Taiwan, it's essentially about defence and security,\" he said.\n\n- Threat of conflict -\n\nAustin and Dong will also give speeches this weekend at the Shangri-La Dialogue in which they are expected to touch on a range of their nations' pressure points.\n\nThe United States is increasingly worried about China's fast-developing military capabilities.\n\nChina already has the largest navy in the world and this month carried out a sea test of its third and biggest aircraft carrier.\n\nIn 2021, China reportedly stunned US defence officials with a globe-circling hypersonic test flight involving a high-speed missile launch over the South China Sea.\n\nIn Beijing, China's leaders are enraged by the United States routinely deploying warships and fighter jets in the Taiwan Strait and South China Sea.\n\nChina views this as part of a decades-long US effort to contain it.\n\n\"If the United States does not hit the brakes but continues to speed down the wrong path, no amount of guardrails can prevent derailing, and there will surely be conflict and confrontation,\" China's then-foreign minister Qin Gang said last year.\n\nSong Zhongping, a Chinese military analyst and former People's Liberation Army officer, told AFP that Dong's Singapore speech would likely include a call for the United States to stop \"provoking\" China on Taiwan and the South China Sea.\n\n\"We especially want to warn certain countries from outside the region -- the US, Japan -- that interfering in the Taiwan Strait and the South China Sea will inevitably cause serious regional conflict,\" he said.\n\nSong also downplayed the prospects of deeper US-China military dialogue unless the United States cut its support for Taiwan.\n\n\"If the US cannot turn a new leaf on this issue, it cannot achieve results no matter who it speaks with.\"\n\nburs-mba/amj/kma/pbt\n\nMore from this section\n\nAt least 22 dead in Memorial Day weekend storms that devastated several US states\n\nUniFab All-In-One software launches latest update to comprehensively improve audio and video processing experience\n\nClosing arguments, jury instructions and maybe a verdict? {"uri": "8151265642", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-29", "time": "09:05:37", "dateTime": "2024-05-29T09:05:37Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-29T09:05:09Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.9215686321258545, "url": "https://www.manilatimes.net/2024/05/29/world/asia-oceania/us-china-defense-chiefs-to-hold-rare-talks-in-singapore/1948981", "title": "US, China defense chiefs to hold rare talks in Singapore", "body": "SINGAPORE, Singapore -- The US and Chinese defense chiefs are set to hold rare direct talks in Singapore this weekend, offering hopes of further military dialogue aimed at preventing flashpoint disputes from spinning out of control.\n\nThe expected meeting between the United States' Lloyd Austin and China's Dong Jun at the Shangri-La Dialogue will be the first substantive face-to-face talks between their countries' defense chiefs in 18 months.\n\nThe security forum is an annual gathering of defense chiefs from around the world that has in recent years become a barometer of US-China relations.\n\nThis year's edition, starting Friday, will come a week after China held military drills around Taiwan and warned of war over the island.\n\nThe dispute over democratic and US-backed Taiwan, which China has vowed to bring under its control, is the highest-profile of many rows between the global powers.\n\nGet the latest news\n\ndelivered to your inbox Sign up for The Manila Times newsletters By signing up with an email address, I acknowledge that I have read and agree to the Terms of Service and Privacy Policy.\n\nBeijing is also furious over Washington's deepening defense ties in the Asia-Pacific, particularly with the Philippines.\n\nChina has in recent years grown increasingly assertive in staking its claims in the contested South China Sea, including by building artificial islands and militarizing them.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nIt effectively suspended military talks with the United States in late 2022 in response to then-US House Speaker Nancy Pelosi's visit to Taiwan.\n\nThe two sides agreed after a summit between Chinese leader Xi Jinping and US President Joe Biden in November last year to restart high-level military talks.\n\nAustin and Dong then talked over the phone in April.\n\nTheir meeting in Singapore -- announced by the Pentagon last week -- would be the most substantial encounter on defense since the presidential summit.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nHowever, the two sides have yet to resume much of the direct military dialogue that was scrapped after Pelosi's Taiwan visit.\n\n\"The hope here is for the (Dong-Austin) meeting to be the beginnings of cautious rapprochement to re-establish military-to-military open lines of communication,\" Mustafa Izzuddin, senior international affairs analyst with consultancy Solaris Strategies Singapore, told Agence France-Presse.\n\nBiden and Xi agreed at their summit to set up a communications channel between the US Indo-Pacific Command chief and China's commanders responsible for military operations near Taiwan, Japan and in the South China Sea.\n\nA US official recently highlighted the importance of direct talks between those commanders.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nIzzuddin described such dialogue as \"essential.\"\n\n\"It's exceptionally important because when we talk about what is happening in the South China Sea and Taiwan, it's essentially about defense and security,\" he said.\n\nThreat of conflict\n\nAustin and Dong will also give speeches this weekend at the Shangri-La Dialogue in which they are expected to touch on a range of their nations' pressure points.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nThe United States is increasingly worried about China's fast-developing military capabilities.\n\nChina already has the largest navy in the world and this month carried out a sea test of its third and biggest aircraft carrier.\n\nIn 2021, China reportedly stunned US defense officials with a globe-circling hypersonic test flight involving a high-speed missile launch over the South China Sea.\n\nIn Beijing, China's leaders are enraged by the United States routinely deploying warships and fighter jets in the Taiwan Strait and South China Sea.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nChina views this as part of a decades-long US effort to contain it.\n\n\"If the United States does not hit the brakes but continues to speed down the wrong path, no amount of guardrails can prevent derailing, and there will surely be conflict and confrontation,\" China's then-foreign minister Qin Gang said last year.\n\nSong Zhongping, a Chinese military analyst and former People's Liberation Army officer, told AFP that Dong's Singapore speech would likely include a call for the United States to stop \"provoking\" China on Taiwan and the South China Sea.\n\n\"We especially want to warn certain countries from outside the region -- the US, Japan -- that interfering in the Taiwan Strait and the South China Sea will inevitably cause serious regional conflict,\" he said.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nSong also downplayed the prospects of deeper US-China military dialogue unless the United States cut its support for Taiwan.\n\n\"If the US cannot turn a new {"uri": "2024-05-371867728", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-29", "time": "09:36:56", "dateTime": "2024-05-29T09:36:56Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-29T09:33:22Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.9176470637321472, "url": "https://www.philstar.com/headlines/2024/05/29/2358900/us-china-defense-chiefs-hold-rare-talks-singapore", "title": "US, China defense chiefs to hold rare talks in Singapore", "body": "SINGAPORE, Singapore -- The US and Chinese defense chiefs are set to hold rare direct talks in Singapore this weekend, offering hopes of further military dialogue aimed at preventing flashpoint disputes from spinning out of control.\n\nThe expected meeting between the United States' Lloyd Austin and China's Dong Jun at the Shangri-La Dialogue will be the first substantive face-to-face talks between their countries' defense chiefs in 18 months.\n\nThe security forum is an annual gathering of defense chiefs from around the world that has in recent years become a barometer of US-China relations.\n\nThis year's edition, starting Friday, will come a week after China held military drills around Taiwan and warned of war over the island.\n\nThe dispute over democratic and US-backed Taiwan, which China has vowed to bring under its control, is the highest-profile of many rows between the global powers.\n\nBeijing is also furious over Washington's deepening defense ties in the Asia-Pacific, particularly with the Philippines.\n\nChina has in recent years grown increasingly assertive in staking its claims in the contested South China Sea, including by building artificial islands and militarising them.\n\nIt effectively suspended military talks with the United States in late 2022 in response to then-US House Speaker Nancy Pelosi's visit to Taiwan.\n\nThe two sides agreed after a summit between Chinese leader Xi Jinping and US President Joe Biden in November last year to restart high-level military talks.\n\nAustin and Dong then talked over the phone in April.\n\nTheir meeting in Singapore -- announced by the Pentagon last week -- would be the most substantial encounter on defense since the presidential summit.\n\nHowever, the two sides have yet to resume much of the direct military dialogue that was scrapped after Pelosi's Taiwan visit.\n\n\"The hope here is for the (Dong-Austin) meeting to be the beginnings of cautious rapprochement to re-establish military-to-military open lines of communication,\" Mustafa Izzuddin, senior international affairs analyst with consultancy Solaris Strategies Singapore, told AFP.\n\nBiden and Xi agreed at their summit to set up a communications channel between the US Indo-Pacific Command chief and China's commanders responsible for military operations near Taiwan, Japan and in the South China Sea.\n\nA US official recently highlighted the importance of direct talks between those commanders.\n\nIzzuddin described such dialogue as \"essential\".\n\n\"It's exceptionally important because when we talk about what is happening in the South China Sea and Taiwan, it's essentially about defense and security,\" he said.\n\nThreat of conflict\n\nAustin and Dong will also give speeches this weekend at the Shangri-La Dialogue in which they are expected to touch on a range of their nations' pressure points.\n\nThe United States is increasingly worried about China's fast-developing military capabilities.\n\nChina already has the largest navy in the world and this month carried out a sea test of its third and biggest aircraft carrier.\n\nIn 2021, China reportedly stunned US defense officials with a globe-circling hypersonic test flight involving a high-speed missile launch over the South China Sea.\n\nIn Beijing, China's leaders are enraged by the United States routinely deploying warships and fighter jets in the Taiwan Strait and South China Sea.\n\nChina views this as part of a decades-long US effort to contain it.\n\n\"If the United States does not hit the brakes but continues to speed down the wrong path, no amount of guardrails can prevent derailing, and there will surely be conflict and confrontation,\" China's then-foreign minister Qin Gang said last year.\n\nSong Zhongping, a Chinese military analyst and former People's Liberation Army officer, told AFP that Dong's Singapore speech would likely include a call for the United States to stop \"provoking\" China on Taiwan and the South China Sea.\n\n\"We especially want to warn certain countries from outside the region -- the US, Japan -- that interfering in the Taiwan Strait and the South China Sea will inevitably cause serious regional conflict,\" he said.\n\nSong also downplayed the prospects of deeper US-China military dialogue unless the United States cut its support for Taiwan.\n\n\"If the US cannot turn a new leaf on this issue, it cannot achieve results no matter who it speaks with.\"", "source": {"uri": "philstar.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Philstar.com"}, "U.S. Defense Secretary Lloyd Austin is set to meet his Chinese counterpart, Dong Jun, in Singapore (Mandel NGAN/AFP)\n\nThe U.S. and Chinese defense chiefs are set to hold rare direct talks in Singapore this weekend, offering hopes of further military dialogue aimed at preventing flashpoint disputes from spinning out of control.\n\nThe expected meeting between the United States' Lloyd Austin and China's Dong Jun at the Shangri-La Dialogue will be the first substantive face-to-face talks between their countries' defence chiefs in 18 months.\n\nThe security forum is an annual gathering of defense chiefs from around the world that has in recent years become a barometer of U.S.-China relations.\n\nThis year's edition, starting Friday, will come a week after China held military drills around Taiwan and warned of war over the island.\n\nThe dispute over democratic and U.S.-backed Taiwan, which China has vowed to bring under its control, is the highest-profile of many rows between the global powers.\n\nBeijing is also furious over Washington's deepening defenc]se ties in the Asia-Pacific, particularly with the Philippines.\n\nChina has in recent years grown increasingly assertive in staking its claims in the contested South China Sea, including by building artificial islands and militarizing them.\n\nIt effectively suspended military talks with the United States in late 2022 in response to then-US House Speaker Nancy Pelosi's visit to Taiwan.\n\nThe two sides agreed after a summit between Chinese leader Xi Jinping and U.S. President Joe Biden in November last year to restart high-level military talks.\n\nAustin and Dong then talked over the phone in April.\n\nTheir meeting in Singapore -- announced by the Pentagon last week -- would be the most substantial encounter on defense since the presidential summit.\n\nHowever, the two sides have yet to resume much of the direct military dialogue that was scrapped after Pelosi's Taiwan visit.\n\n\"The hope here is for the (Dong-Austin) meeting to be the beginnings of cautious rapprochement to re-establish military-to-military open lines of communication,\" Mustafa Izzuddin, senior international affairs analyst with consultancy Solaris Strategies Singapore, told AFP.\n\nBiden and Xi agreed at their summit to set up a communications channel between the U.S. Indo-Pacific Command chief and China's commanders responsible for military operations near Taiwan, Japan and in the South China Sea.\n\nA US official recently highlighted the importance of direct talks between those commanders.\n\nIzzuddin described such dialogue as \"essential\".\n\n\"It's exceptionally important because when we talk about what is happening in the South China Sea and Taiwan, it's essentially about defense and security,\" he said.\n\n- Threat of conflict -\n\nAustin and Dong will also give speeches this weekend at the Shangri-La Dialogue in which they are expected to touch on a range of their nations' pressure points.\n\nThe United States is increasingly worried about China's fast-developing military capabilities.\n\nChina already has the largest navy in the world and this month carried out a sea test of its third and biggest aircraft carrier.\n\nIn 2021, China reportedly stunned U.S. defense officials with a globe-circling hypersonic test flight involving a high-speed missile launch over the South China Sea.\n\nIn Beijing, China's leaders are enraged by the United States routinely deploying warships and fighter jets in the Taiwan Strait and South China Sea.\n\nChina views this as part of a decades-long U.S. effort to contain it.\n\n\"If the United States does not hit the brakes but continues to speed down the wrong path, no amount of guardrails can prevent derailing, and there will surely be conflict and confrontation,\" China's then-foreign minister Qin Gang said last year.\n\nSong Zhongping, a Chinese military analyst and former People's "sim": 0.8823529481887817, "url": "https://www.fox28spokane.com/us-chinese-defence-chiefs-meet-in-singapore/", "title": "US, Chinese defence chiefs meet in Singapore | FOX 28 Spokane", "body": "The US and Chinese defence chiefs held rare direct talks in Singapore on Friday, offering hopes for more military dialogue that could help prevent disputes over Taiwan and other flashpoint issues from spinning out of control.\n\nThe meeting between the United States' Lloyd Austin and China's Dong Jun on the sidelines of the Shangri-La Dialogue is the first substantive face-to-face talks between the two countries' defence chiefs in 18 months.\n\nDong and Austin began the talks shortly before 1:00 pm (0500 GMT) at the luxury hotel hosting the security forum, a member of the US delegation told reporters.\n\nDefence chiefs and officials from around the world are attending the annual forum that has in recent years become a barometer of US-China relations.\n\nThis year's edition comes a week after China held military drills around Taiwan and warned of war over the US-backed island following the inauguration of President Lai Ching-te, who Beijing has described as a \"dangerous separatist\".\n\nThe dispute over democratic Taiwan, which Beijing considers part of its territory, tops the list of disputes between the rivals.\n\nBeijing is also furious over Washington's deepening defence ties in the Asia-Pacific, particularly with the Philippines, and its regular deployment of warships and fighter jets in the Taiwan Strait and South China Sea.\n\nChina views this as part of a decades-long US effort to contain it.\n\nPresident Joe Biden's administration and China have been stepping up communication to ease friction between the nuclear-armed rivals, with Secretary of State Antony Blinken visiting Beijing and Shanghai last month.\n\nA key focus has been the resumption of military-to-military dialogue.\n\nChina scrapped military communications with the United States in 2022 in response to then-US House Speaker Nancy Pelosi's visit to Taiwan.\n\nTensions between Washington and Beijing were stoked further during 2023 by issues including an alleged Chinese spy balloon that was shot down over US airspace, a meeting between Taiwan's then-president Tsai Ing-wen and Pelosi's successor Kevin McCarthy, and American military aid for Taipei.\n\nThe two sides agreed after a summit between Chinese leader Xi Jinping and Biden in November last year to restart high-level military talks.\n\n- Pressure points -\n\nThat includes a communications channel between the US Indo-Pacific Command chief and Chinese commanders responsible for military operations near Taiwan, Japan and in the South China Sea.\n\nChinese and American forces have had a series of close encounters in the disputed waterway that China claims almost entirely.\n\nAustin warned prior to Biden and Xi agreeing to resume military-to-military dialogue that accidents have the potential to spiral out of control, especially in the absence of open lines of communication between American and Chinese forces.\n\nFriday's meeting between Austin and Dong follows a phone call between the pair in April, and offers hope of further military talks to cool tensions.\n\nAustin and Dong will give speeches this weekend at the Shangri-La Dialogue in which they are expected to touch on a range of their nations' pressure points.\n\nThe United States, increasingly worried about China's fast-developing military capabilities, has been strengthening its alliances and partnerships in the region to counter China's growing assertiveness over Taiwan and in the South China Sea.\n\nIn a post on X early Friday announcing his arrival in Singapore, Austin said he would meet with regional counterparts and continue his department's work with \"like-minded Indo-Pacific partners to promote our shared vision for a free and open region\".\n\nPhilippine President Ferdinand Marcos, who has sought to deepen defence cooperation with the United States as he stands up to Chinese actions in waters off the Southeast Asia country, will deliver the Shangri-La Dialogue's keynote speech on Lloyd Austin and Dong Jun met to discuss military dialogue and tensions over Taiwan and other issues.The US and Chinese defence chiefs held rare direct talks in Singapore on Friday, offering hopes for more military dialogue that could help prevent disputes over Taiwan and other flashpoint issues from spinning out of control.\n\nThe meeting between the United States' Lloyd Austin and China's Dong Jun on the sidelines of the Shangri-La Dialogue is the first substantive face-to-face talks between the two countries' defence chiefs in 18 months.\n\nDong and Austin began the talks shortly before 1:00 pm (0500 GMT) at the luxury hotel hosting the security forum, a member of the US delegation told reporters.\n\nDefence chiefs and officials from around the world are attending the annual forum that has in recent years become a barometer of US-China relations.\n\nThis year's edition comes a week after China held military drills around Taiwan and warned of war over the US-backed island following the inauguration of President Lai Ching-te, who Beijing has described as a \"dangerous separatist\".\n\nThe dispute over democratic Taiwan, which Beijing considers part of its territory, tops the list of disputes between the rivals.\n\nBeijing is also furious over Washington's deepening defence ties in the Asia-Pacific, particularly with the Philippines, and its regular deployment of warships and fighter jets in the Taiwan Strait and South China Sea.\n\nChina views this as part of a decades-long US effort to contain it.\n\nPresident Joe Biden's administration and China have been stepping up communication to ease friction between the nuclear-armed rivals, with Secretary of State Antony Blinken visiting Beijing and Shanghai last month.\n\nA key focus has been the resumption of military-to-military dialogue.\n\nChina scrapped military communications with the United States in 2022 in response to then-US House Speaker Nancy Pelosi's visit to Taiwan.\n\nTensions between Washington and Beijing were stoked further during 2023 by issues including an alleged Chinese spy balloon that was shot down over US airspace, a meeting between Taiwan's then-president Tsai Ing-wen and Pelosi's successor Kevin McCarthy, and American military aid for Taipei.\n\nThe two sides agreed after a summit between Chinese leader Xi Jinping and Biden in November last year to restart high-level military talks.\n\nPressure points\n\nThat includes a communications channel between the US Indo-Pacific Command chief and Chinese commanders responsible for military operations near Taiwan, Japan and in the South China Sea.\n\nChinese and American forces have had a series of close encounters in the disputed waterway that China claims almost entirely.\n\nAustin warned prior to Biden and Xi agreeing to resume military-to-military dialogue that accidents have the potential to spiral out of control, especially in the absence of open lines of communication between American and Chinese forces.\n\nFriday's meeting between Austin and Dong follows a phone call between the pair in April, and offers hope of further military talks to cool tensions.\n\nAustin and Dong will give speeches this weekend at the Shangri-La Dialogue in which they are expected to touch on a range of their nations' pressure points.\n\nThe United States, increasingly worried about China's fast-developing military capabilities, has been strengthening its alliances and partnerships in the region to counter China's growing assertiveness over Taiwan and in the South China Sea.\n\nIn a post on X early Friday announcing his arrival in Singapore, Austin said he would meet with regional counterparts and continue his department's work with \"like-minded Indo-Pacific partners to promote our shared vision for a free and open region\".\n\nPhilippine President Ferdinand Marcos, who has sought to deepen defence cooperation with the United States as he stands up to Chinese actions in waters off the Southeast Asia country, will deliver the Shangri-La Dialogue's keynote speech on Friday.", "source": {"uri": "economictimes.indiatimes.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Economic Times"}, "sim": 0.8745098114013672, "url": "https://www.dailymail.co.uk/wires/afp/article-13479093/US-Chinese-defence-chiefs-meet-Singapore.html", "title": "US, Chinese defence chiefs meet in Singapore", "body": "Police officers stand watch outside Singapore's Shangri-La Hotel on Friday, site of a yearly defence chiefs meeting increasingly seen as a barometer of US-China relations\n\nThe US and Chinese defence chiefs held rare direct talks in Singapore on Friday, offering hopes for more military dialogue that could help prevent disputes over Taiwan and other flashpoint issues from spinning out of control.\n\nThe meeting between the United States' Lloyd Austin and China's Dong Jun on the sidelines of the Shangri-La Dialogue is the first substantive face-to-face talks between the two countries' defence chiefs in 18 months.\n\nDong and Austin began the talks shortly before 1:00 pm (0500 GMT) at the luxury hotel hosting the security forum, a member of the US delegation told reporters.\n\nDefence chiefs and officials from around the world are attending the annual forum that has in recent years become a barometer of US-China relations.\n\nThis year's edition comes a week after China held military drills around Taiwan and warned of war over the US-backed island following the inauguration of President Lai Ching-te, who Beijing has described as a \"dangerous separatist\".\n\nThe dispute over democratic Taiwan, which Beijing considers part of its territory, tops the list of disputes between the rivals.\n\nBeijing is also furious over Washington's deepening defence ties in the Asia-Pacific, particularly with the Philippines, and its regular deployment of warships and fighter jets in the Taiwan Strait and South China Sea.\n\nChina views this as part of a decades-long US effort to contain it.\n\nPresident Joe Biden's administration and China have been stepping up communication to ease friction between the nuclear-armed rivals, with Secretary of State Antony Blinken visiting Beijing and Shanghai last month.\n\nA key focus has been the resumption of military-to-military dialogue.\n\nChina scrapped military communications with the United States in 2022 in response to then-US House Speaker Nancy Pelosi's visit to Taiwan.\n\nTensions between Washington and Beijing were stoked further during 2023 by issues including an alleged Chinese spy balloon that was shot down over US airspace, a meeting between Taiwan's then-president Tsai Ing-wen and Pelosi's successor Kevin McCarthy, and American military aid for Taipei.\n\nThe two sides agreed after a summit between Chinese leader Xi Jinping and Biden in November last year to restart high-level military talks.\n\n- Pressure points -\n\nThat includes a communications channel between the US Indo-Pacific Command chief and Chinese commanders responsible for military operations near Taiwan, Japan and in the South China Sea.\n\nChinese and American forces have had a series of close encounters in the disputed waterway that China claims almost entirely.\n\nAustin warned prior to Biden and Xi agreeing to resume military-to-military dialogue that accidents have the potential to spiral out of control, especially in the absence of open lines of communication between American and Chinese forces.\n\nFriday's meeting between Austin and Dong follows a phone call between the pair in April, and offers hope of further military talks to cool tensions.\n\nAustin and Dong will give speeches this weekend at the Shangri-La Dialogue in which they are expected to touch on a range of their nations' pressure points.\n\nThe United States, increasingly worried about China's fast-developing military capabilities, has been strengthening its alliances and partnerships in the region to counter China's growing assertiveness over Taiwan and in the South China Sea.\n\nIn a post on X early Friday announcing his arrival in Singapore, Austin said he would meet with regional counterparts and continue his department's work with \"like-minded Indo-Pacific partners to promote our shared vision for a free and open region\".\n\nPhilippine President Ferdinand Marcos, who has sought to deepen defence cooperation with the United States as he stands up to Chinese actions in waters off the Southeast Asia country, will deliver the Shangri-La Dialogue\u00b4s keynote speech on Friday.", {"uri": "2024-05-374098316", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-31", "time": "06:48:11", "dateTime": "2024-05-31T06:48:11Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-31T06:46:17Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8705882430076599, "url": "https://www.philstar.com/world/2024/05/31/2359382/us-chinese-defense-chiefs-meet-singapore", "title": "US, Chinese defense chiefs meet in Singapore", "body": "SINGAPORE, Singapore -- The US and Chinese defense chiefs held rare direct talks in Singapore on Friday, offering hopes for more military dialogue that could help prevent disputes over Taiwan and other flashpoint issues from spinning out of control.\n\nThe meeting between the United States' Lloyd Austin and China's Dong Jun on the sidelines of the Shangri-La Dialogue was the first substantive face-to-face talks between the two defense chiefs in 18 months.\n\nDong and Austin met for more than an hour at the luxury hotel hosting the security forum. Both men left the meeting room separately shortly after 2:00 pm (0600 GMT).\n\nDefense chiefs and officials from around the world are attending the annual forum that has in recent years become a barometer of US-China relations.\n\nThis year's edition comes a week after China held military drills around Taiwan and warned of war over the US-backed island following the inauguration of President Lai Ching-te, who Beijing has described as a \"dangerous separatist\".\n\nDemocratic Taiwan, which Beijing considers part of its territory, tops the list of disputes between the rivals.\n\nBeijing is also furious over Washington's deepening defense ties in the Asia-Pacific, particularly with the Philippines, and its regular deployment of warships and fighter jets in the Taiwan Strait and South China Sea.\n\nChina views this as part of a decades-long US effort to contain it.\n\nUS President Joe Biden's administration and China have been stepping up communication to ease friction between the nuclear-armed rivals, with Secretary of State Antony Blinken visiting Beijing and Shanghai last month.\n\nA key focus has been the resumption of military-to-military dialogue.\n\nChina scrapped military communications with the United States in 2022 in response to then-US House Speaker Nancy Pelosi's visit to Taiwan.\n\nTensions between Washington and Beijing were stoked further during 2023 by issues including an alleged Chinese spy balloon that was shot down over US airspace, a meeting between Taiwan's then-president Tsai Ing-wen and Pelosi's successor Kevin McCarthy, and American military aid for Taipei.\n\nThe two sides agreed after a summit between Chinese leader Xi Jinping and Biden in November last year to restart high-level military talks.\n\nThat includes a communications channel between the US Indo-Pacific Command chief and Chinese commanders responsible for military operations near Taiwan, Japan and in the South China Sea.\n\nPressure points\n\nChinese and American forces have had a series of close encounters in the disputed waterway that China claims almost entirely.\n\nAustin warned prior to Biden and Xi agreeing to resume military-to-military dialogue that accidents have the potential to spiral out of control, especially in the absence of open lines of communication between American and Chinese forces.\n\nFriday's meeting between Austin and Dong follows a phone call between the pair in April, and offers hope of further military talks to cool tensions.\n\nAustin and Dong will give speeches this weekend at the Shangri-La Dialogue in which they are expected to touch on a range of their nations' pressure points.\n\nThe United States, increasingly worried about China's fast-developing military capabilities, has been strengthening its alliances and partnerships in the region to counter China's growing assertiveness over Taiwan and in the South China Sea.\n\nIn a post on X early Friday announcing his arrival in Singapore, Austin said he would meet with regional counterparts and continue his department's work with \"like-minded Indo-Pacific partners to promote our shared vision for a free and open region\".\n\nPhilippine President Ferdinand Marcos, who has sought to deepen defense cooperation with the United States as he stands up to Chinese actions in waters off the Southeast Asia country, will deliver the Shangri-La {"uri": "8151522883", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-29", "time": "11:37:22", "dateTime": "2024-05-29T11:37:22Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-29T11:36:49Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8705882430076599, "url": "https://saharareporters.com/2024/05/29/us-china-top-officials-meet-singapore-rare-military-talks", "title": "US, China Top Officials Meet In Singapore For Rare Military Talks", "body": "China had in 2023 declined a request from the United States for a meeting between their defense chiefs at an annual security forum in Singapore this weekend, media reported on Monday, a new sign of strain between the powers.\n\nThe United States and Chinese defence chiefs are set to meet in Singapore this weekend, to hold rare direct talks.\n\nThe development is said to offer hopes of further military dialogue aimed at preventing flashpoint disputes from spinning out of control.\n\nChina had in 2023 declined a request from the United States for a meeting between their defense chiefs at an annual security forum in Singapore this weekend, media reported on Monday, a new sign of strain between the powers.\n\n\"Overnight, the PRC informed the U.S. that they have declined our early May invitation for Secretary (Lloyd) Austin to meet with PRC Minister of National Defense Li Shangfu in Singapore,\" the Pentagon said in a statement to the Wall Street Journal, referring to China by the initials of its official name, the People's Republic of China.\n\nHowever, AFP reports that the expected meeting between the United States' Lloyd Austin and China's Dong Jun at the Shangri-La Dialogue will be the first substantive face-to-face talks between their countries' defence chiefs in 18 months.\n\nThe security forum is an annual gathering of defence chiefs from around the world that has in recent years become a barometer of US-China relations. While this year's edition, starting Friday, will come a week after China held military drills around Taiwan and warned of war over the island.\n\nThe dispute over democratic and US-backed Taiwan, which China has vowed to bring under its control, is the highest-profile of many rows between the global powers. Beijing is also furious over Washington's deepening defence ties in the Asia-Pacific, particularly with the Philippines.\n\nChina has in recent years grown increasingly assertive in staking its claims in the contested South China Sea, including by building artificial islands and militarising them.\n\nIt effectively suspended military talks with the United States in late 2022 in response to then-US House Speaker Nancy Pelosi's visit to Taiwan.\n\nThe two sides agreed after a summit between Chinese leader Xi Jinping and US President Joe Biden in November last year to restart high-level military talks.\n\nAustin and Dong then talked over the phone in April.\n\nTheir meeting in Singapore -- announced by the Pentagon last week -- would be the most substantial encounter on defence since the presidential summit.\n\nHowever, the two sides have yet to resume much of the direct military dialogue that was scrapped after Pelosi's Taiwan visit.\n\n\"The hope here is for the (Dong-Austin) meeting to be the beginnings of cautious rapprochement to re-establish military-to-military open lines of communication,\" Mustafa Izzuddin, senior international affairs analyst with consultancy Solaris Strategies Singapore, told AFP.\n\nBiden and Xi agreed at their summit to set up a communications channel between the US Indo-Pacific Command chief and China's commanders responsible for military operations near Taiwan, Japan and in the South China Sea.\n\nA US official recently highlighted the importance of direct talks between those commanders. Izzuddin described such dialogue as \"essential\".\n\n\"It's exceptionally important because when we talk about what is happening in the South China Sea and Taiwan, it's essentially about defence and {"uri": "8154417469", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-31", "time": "04:27:08", "dateTime": "2024-05-31T04:27:08Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-31T04:26:38Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8705882430076599, "url": "https://www.malaymail.com/news/world/2024/05/31/us-chinese-defence-chiefs-set-to-meet-in-singapore/137402", "title": "US, Chinese defence chiefs set to meet in Singapore", "body": "SINGAPORE, May 31 -- The US and Chinese defence chiefs will hold rare direct talks in Singapore today, offering hopes for more military dialogue that could help prevent disputes over Taiwan and other flashpoint issues from spinning out of control.\n\nThe meeting between the United States' Lloyd Austin and China's Dong Jun on the sidelines of the Shangri-La Dialogue will be the first substantive face-to-face talks between the two countries' defence chiefs in 18 months.\n\nDong and Austin are scheduled to meet at 1pm at the luxury hotel hosting the security forum, members of the US delegation told AFP on the condition of anonymity.\n\nDefence chiefs and officials from around the world are attending the annual forum that has in recent years become a barometer of US-China relations.\n\nThis year's edition comes a week after China held military drills around Taiwan and warned of war over the US-backed island following the inauguration of President Lai Ching-te, who Beijing has described as a \"dangerous separatist\".\n\nThe dispute over democratic Taiwan, which Beijing considers part of its territory, tops the list of disputes between the rivals.\n\nBeijing is also furious over Washington's deepening defence ties in the Asia-Pacific, particularly with the Philippines, and its regular deployment of warships and fighter jets in the Taiwan Strait and South China Sea.\n\nChina views this as part of a decades-long US effort to contain it.\n\nPresident Joe Biden's administration and China have been stepping up communication to ease friction between the nuclear-armed rivals, with Secretary of State Antony Blinken visiting Beijing and Shanghai last month.\n\nA key focus has been the resumption of military-to-military dialogue.\n\nChina scrapped military communications with the United States in 2022 in response to then-US House Speaker Nancy Pelosi's visit to Taiwan.\n\nTensions between Washington and Beijing were stoked further during 2023 by issues including an alleged Chinese spy balloon that was shot down over US airspace, a meeting between Taiwan's then-president Tsai Ing-wen and Pelosi's successor Kevin McCarthy, and American military aid for Taipei.\n\nThe two sides agreed after a summit between Chinese leader Xi Jinping and Biden in November last year to restart high-level military talks.\n\nPressure points\n\nThat includes a communications channel between the US Indo-Pacific Command chief and Chinese commanders responsible for military operations near Taiwan, Japan and in the South China Sea.\n\nChinese and American forces have had a series of close encounters in the disputed waterway that China claims almost entirely.\n\nAustin warned prior to Biden and Xi agreeing to resume military-to-military dialogue that accidents have the potential to spiral out of control, especially in the absence of open lines of communication between American and Chinese forces.\n\nThe highly anticipated meeting between Austin and Dong follows a phone call between the pair in April, and offers hope of further military talks to cool tensions.\n\nAustin and Dong will give speeches this weekend at the Shangri-La Dialogue in which they are expected to touch on a range of their nations' pressure points.\n\nThe United States, increasingly worried about China's fast-developing military capabilities, has been strengthening its alliances and partnerships in the region to counter China's growing assertiveness over Taiwan and in the South China Sea.\n\nIn a post on X early Friday announcing his arrival in Singapore, Austin said he would meet with regional counterparts and continue his department's work with \"like-minded Indo-Pacific partners to promote our shared vision for a free and open region\".\n\nPhilippine President Ferdinand Marcos, who has sought to deepen defence cooperation with the United States as he stands up to Chinese actions in waters off the South-east Asia country, will deliver the Shangri-La Dialogue's keynote speech on Friday. -- AFP", "source": {"uri": "malaymail.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Malay Mail"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "sim": 0.8666666746139526, "url": "https://www.urdupoint.com/en/world/us-china-defence-chiefs-to-hold-rare-talks-i-1829861.html", "title": "US, China Defence Chiefs To Hold Rare Talks In Singapore - UrduPoint", "body": "Singapore, (APP - UrduPoint / Pakistan Point News - 29th May, 2024) The US and Chinese defence chiefs are set to hold rare direct talks in Singapore this weekend, offering hopes of further military dialogue aimed at preventing flashpoint disputes from spinning out of control.\n\nThis year's edition, starting Friday, will come a week after China held military drills around Taiwan and warned of war over the island.\n\nThe dispute over democratic and US-backed Taiwan, which China has vowed to bring under its control, is the highest-profile of many rows between the global powers.\n\nBeijing is also furious over Washington's deepening defence ties in the Asia-Pacific, particularly with the Philippines.\n\nChina has in recent years grown increasingly assertive in staking its claims in the contested South China Sea, including by building artificial islands and militarising them.\n\nHowever, the two sides have yet to resume much of the direct military dialogue that was scrapped after Pelosi's Taiwan visit.\n\n\"The hope here is for the (Dong-Austin) meeting to be the beginnings of cautious rapprochement to re-establish military-to-military open lines of communication,\" Mustafa Izzuddin, senior international affairs analyst with consultancy Solaris Strategies Singapore, told AFP.\n\nA US official recently highlighted the importance of direct talks between those commanders.\n\nIzzuddin described such dialogue as \"essential\".\n\n\"It's exceptionally important because when we talk about what is happening in the South China Sea and Taiwan, it's essentially about defence and security,\" he said.\n\nAustin and Dong will also give speeches this weekend at the Shangri-La Dialogue in which they are expected to touch on a range of their nations' pressure points.\n\n\"If the United States does not hit the brakes but continues to speed down the wrong path, no amount of guardrails can prevent derailing, and there will surely be conflict and confrontation,\" China's then-foreign minister Qin Gang said last year.\n\nSong also downplayed the prospects of deeper US-China military dialogue unless the United States cut its support for {"uri": "8154559304", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-31", "time": "06:26:48", "dateTime": "2024-05-31T06:26:48Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-31T06:26:13Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8627451062202454, "url": "https://www.reformer.com/news/national/us-chinese-defence-chiefs-meet-in-singapore/article_a9c6873f-da07-5779-bf2a-c9dbff3a52e9.html", "title": "US, Chinese defence chiefs meet in Singapore", "body": "The US and Chinese defence chiefs held rare direct talks in Singapore on Friday, offering hopes for more military dialogue that could help prevent disputes over Taiwan and other flashpoint issues from spinning out of control.\n\nThe meeting between the United States' Lloyd Austin and China's Dong Jun on the sidelines of the Shangri-La Dialogue is the first substantive face-to-face talks between the two countries' defence chiefs in 18 months.\n\nDong and Austin began the talks shortly before 1:00 pm (0500 GMT) at the luxury hotel hosting the security forum, a member of the US delegation told reporters.\n\nDefence chiefs and officials from around the world are attending the annual forum that has in recent years become a barometer of US-China relations.\n\nThis year's edition comes a week after China held military drills around Taiwan and warned of war over the US-backed island following the inauguration of President Lai Ching-te, who Beijing has described as a \"dangerous separatist\".\n\nThe dispute over democratic Taiwan, which Beijing considers part of its territory, tops the list of disputes between the rivals.\n\nBeijing is also furious over Washington's deepening defence ties in the Asia-Pacific, particularly with the Philippines, and its regular deployment of warships and fighter jets in the Taiwan Strait and South China Sea.\n\nChina views this as part of a decades-long US effort to contain it.\n\nPresident Joe Biden's administration and China have been stepping up communication to ease friction between the nuclear-armed rivals, with Secretary of State Antony Blinken visiting Beijing and Shanghai last month.\n\nA key focus has been the resumption of military-to-military dialogue.\n\nChina scrapped military communications with the United States in 2022 in response to then-US House Speaker Nancy Pelosi's visit to Taiwan.\n\nTensions between Washington and Beijing were stoked further during 2023 by issues including an alleged Chinese spy balloon that was shot down over US airspace, a meeting between Taiwan's then-president Tsai Ing-wen and Pelosi's successor Kevin McCarthy, and American military aid for Taipei.\n\nMore from this section Report: 4 in 5 New Jersey nursing homes don't meet new federal standards Look inside Fort Worth Zoo's new Exploration & Learning Center Legal battle over cracked tarmac at Whitehorse airport sees appeals tossed\n\nThe two sides agreed after a summit between Chinese leader Xi Jinping and Biden in November last year to restart high-level military talks.\n\n- Pressure points -\n\nThat includes a communications channel between the US Indo-Pacific Command chief and Chinese commanders responsible for military operations near Taiwan, Japan and in the South China Sea.\n\nChinese and American forces have had a series of close encounters in the disputed waterway that China claims almost entirely.\n\nAustin warned prior to Biden and Xi agreeing to resume military-to-military dialogue that accidents have the potential to spiral out of control, especially in the absence of open lines of communication between American and Chinese forces.\n\nFriday's meeting between Austin and Dong follows a phone call between the pair in April, and offers hope of further military talks to cool tensions.\n\nAustin and Dong will give speeches this weekend at the Shangri-La Dialogue in which they are expected to touch on a range of their nations' pressure points.\n\nThe United States, increasingly worried about China's fast-developing military capabilities, has been strengthening its alliances and partnerships in the region to counter China's growing assertiveness over Taiwan and in the South China Sea.\n\nIn a post on X early Friday announcing his arrival in Singapore, Austin said he would meet with regional counterparts and continue his department's work with \"like-minded Indo-Pacific partners to promote our shared vision for a free and open region\".\n\nPhilippine President Ferdinand Marcos, who has sought to deepen defence cooperation with the United States as he stands up to Chinese actions in waters off the Southeast Asia country, will deliver the Shangri-La Dialogue's keynote speech on Friday.\n\namj/cwl", "source": {"uri": "reformer.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Brattleboro Reformer"}, "authors": {"uri": "8154880923", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-31", "time": "10:02:01", "dateTime": "2024-05-31T10:02:01Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-31T10:01:22Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8549019694328308, "url": "https://www.firstpost.com/world/us-china-to-resume-military-to-military-dialogue-in-coming-months-says-llyod-austin-13777079.html", "title": "US-China to resume military-to-military dialogue in 'coming months', says Lloyd Austin", "body": "US Secretary of Defence Lloyd Austin and Chinese Defence Minister Dong Jun attend a bilateral meeting in Singapore on 31 May, 2024. Reuters\n\nThe United States and China will resume military-to-military communications \"in the coming months\", US Defense Secretary Lloyd Austin said Friday, as Beijing hailed the \"stabilising\" security relations between the countries.\n\nAustin met with his Chinese counterpart Dong Jun on the sidelines of the Shangri-La Dialogue in Singapore in the first substantive face-to-face talks between the two defence chiefs in 18 months.\n\nDong and Austin met for over an hour at the luxury hotel hosting the security forum that is attended by defence officials from around the world and in recent years has become a barometer of US-China relations.\n\nAustin said telephone conversations between US and Chinese military commanders would resume \"in the coming months\", according to a readout released by the Pentagon.\n\nHe also welcomed plans for a \"crisis-communications working group\" with China by the end of the year, the statement said.\n\nDescribing the talks as \"positive\", Chinese defence spokesman Wu Qian told reporters that military-to-military relations were \"currently stopping their decline and stabilising\".\n\nWu cautioned that it was not possible for Beijing and Washington to solve all bilateral problems in one meeting, but said \"talking is better than not talking\".\n\nThis year's Shangri-La Dialogue comes a week after China held military drills around Taiwan and warned of war over the US-backed island following the inauguration of President Lai Ching-te, who Beijing has described as a \"dangerous separatist\".\n\nSelf-ruled Taiwan, which Beijing considers part of its territory, tops the list of disputes between the rivals.\n\nChina is also furious over the United States' deepening defence ties in the Asia-Pacific, particularly with the Philippines, and its regular deployment of warships and fighter jets in the Taiwan Strait and South China Sea.\n\nBeijing views this as part of a decades-long US effort to contain it.\n\nUS President Joe Biden's administration and China have been stepping up communication to ease friction between the nuclear-armed rivals, with Secretary of State Antony Blinken visiting Beijing and Shanghai last month.\n\nA key focus has been the resumption of military-to-military dialogue, which is seen as critical to preventing flashpoint disputes from spinning out of control.\n\nChina scrapped military communications with the United States in 2022 in response to then-US House Speaker Nancy Pelosi's visit to Taiwan.\n\nTensions between Washington and Beijing were stoked further during 2023 by issues including an alleged Chinese spy balloon that was shot down over US airspace, a meeting between Taiwan's then-president Tsai Ing-wen and Pelosi's successor Kevin McCarthy, and American military aid for Taipei.\n\nThe two sides agreed after a summit between Chinese leader Xi Jinping and Biden last November to restart high-level military talks.\n\nThat includes a communications channel between the US Indo-Pacific Command chief and Chinese commanders responsible for military operations near Taiwan, Japan and in the South China Sea.\n\nPressure points\n\nChinese and American forces have had a series of close encounters in the disputed waterway that China claims almost entirely.\n\nAustin warned prior to Biden and Xi agreeing to resume military-to-military dialogue that accidents have the potential to spiral out of control, especially in the absence of open lines of communication between American and Chinese forces.\n\nFriday's meeting between Austin and Dong follows a phone call between the pair in April, and offers hope of further military talks to cool tensions.\n\nAustin's last significant interaction with a Chinese counterpart was in November 2022 when he met with Wei Fenghe in Cambodia.\n\nWei was subsequently replaced by Li Shangfu, who shook hands and spoke briefly with Austin at the Shangri-La Dialogue in 2023 but did not hold a formal meeting with him.\n\nAustin and Dong will give speeches this weekend at the Shangri-La Dialogue in which they are expected to touch on a range of their nations' pressure points.\n\nThe United States, increasingly worried about China's fast-developing military capabilities, has been strengthening its alliances and partnerships in the region to counter China's growing assertiveness over Taiwan and in the South China Sea.\n\nIn the meeting, Austin underscored the United States' commitment to the one China policy, but insisted that it would continue to \"fly, sail and operate\" wherever international law allowed, the Pentagon readout said.\n\nPhilippine President Ferdinand Marcos, who has sought to deepen defence cooperation with the United States as he stands up to Chinese actions in waters off the Southeast Asia country, will deliver the Shangri-La Dialogue's keynote speech on Friday.", "source": {"uri": "firstpost.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Firstpost"}, "authors": "sim": 0.8549019694328308, "url": "https://www.spacewar.com/afp/240531050733.2ijox75z.html", "title": "US, Chinese defence chiefs meet in Singapore", "body": "The meeting between the United States' Lloyd Austin and China's Dong Jun on the sidelines of the Shangri-La Dialogue is the first substantive face-to-face talks between the two countries' defence chiefs in 18 months.\n\nDong and Austin began the talks shortly before 1:00 pm (0500 GMT) at the luxury hotel hosting the security forum, a member of the US delegation told reporters.\n\nDefence chiefs and officials from around the world are attending the annual forum that has in recent years become a barometer of US-China relations.\n\nThis year's edition comes a week after China held military drills around Taiwan and warned of war over the US-backed island following the inauguration of President Lai Ching-te, who Beijing has described as a \"dangerous separatist\".\n\nThe dispute over democratic Taiwan, which Beijing considers part of its territory, tops the list of disputes between the rivals.\n\nBeijing is also furious over Washington's deepening defence ties in the Asia-Pacific, particularly with the Philippines, and its regular deployment of warships and fighter jets in the Taiwan Strait and South China Sea.\n\nChina views this as part of a decades-long US effort to contain it.\n\nPresident Joe Biden's administration and China have been stepping up communication to ease friction between the nuclear-armed rivals, with Secretary of State Antony Blinken visiting Beijing and Shanghai last month.\n\nA key focus has been the resumption of military-to-military dialogue.\n\nChina scrapped military communications with the United States in 2022 in response to then-US House Speaker Nancy Pelosi's visit to Taiwan.\n\nTensions between Washington and Beijing were stoked further during 2023 by issues including an alleged Chinese spy balloon that was shot down over US airspace, a meeting between Taiwan's then-president Tsai Ing-wen and Pelosi's successor Kevin McCarthy, and American military aid for Taipei.\n\nThe two sides agreed after a summit between Chinese leader Xi Jinping and Biden in November last year to restart high-level military talks.\n\nThat includes a communications channel between the US Indo-Pacific Command chief and Chinese commanders responsible for military operations near Taiwan, Japan and in the South China Sea.\n\nChinese and American forces have had a series of close encounters in the disputed waterway that China claims almost entirely.\n\nAustin warned prior to Biden and Xi agreeing to resume military-to-military dialogue that accidents have the potential to spiral out of control, especially in the absence of open lines of communication between American and Chinese forces.\n\nFriday's meeting between Austin and Dong follows a phone call between the pair in April, and offers hope of further military talks to cool tensions.\n\nAustin and Dong will give speeches this weekend at the Shangri-La Dialogue in which they are expected to touch on a range of their nations' pressure points.\n\nThe United States, increasingly worried about China's fast-developing military capabilities, has been strengthening its alliances and partnerships in the region to counter China's growing assertiveness over Taiwan and in the South China Sea.\n\nIn a post on X early Friday announcing his arrival in Singapore, Austin said he would meet with regional counterparts and continue his department's work with \"like-minded Indo-Pacific partners to promote our shared vision for a free and open region\".\n\nPhilippine President Ferdinand Marcos, who has sought to deepen defence cooperation with the United States as he stands up to Chinese actions in waters off the Southeast Asia country, will deliver the Shangri-La Dialogue's keynote speech on Friday.", "source": {"uri": "spacewar.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "SpaceWar"}, "authors": [],
