{"uri": "8154553385", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-31", "time": "06:23:00", "dateTime": "2024-05-31T06:23:00Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-31T06:21:45Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8509804010391235, "url": "https://www.thehindu.com/news/international/us-chinese-defence-chiefs-meet-in-singapore/article68235154.ece", "title": "US, Chinese defence chiefs meet in Singapore", "body": "The U.S. and Chinese defence chiefs held rare direct talks in Singapore on May 31, offering hopes for more military dialogue that could help prevent disputes over Taiwan and other flashpoint issues from spinning out of control.\n\nThe meeting between the United States' Lloyd Austin and China's Dong Jun on the sidelines of the Shangri-La Dialogue is the first substantive face-to-face talks between the two countries' defence chiefs in 18 months.\n\nMr. Dong and Mr. Austin began the talks shortly before 1:00 p.m. (local time) at the luxury hotel hosting the security forum, a member of the US delegation told reporters.\n\nPolicemen are seen at the Shangri-La Hotel during the 21st Shangri-La Dialogue summit in Singapore on May 31, 2024. | Photo Credit: AFP\n\nDefence chiefs and officials from around the world are attending the annual forum that has in recent years become a barometer of US-China relations.\n\nThis year's edition comes a week after China held military drills around Taiwan and warned of war over the US-backed island following the inauguration of President Lai Ching-te, who Beijing has described as a \"dangerous separatist\".\n\nTaiwan's president says wants to work with China after drills\n\nThe dispute over democratic Taiwan, which Beijing considers part of its territory, tops the list of disputes between the rivals.\n\nRestoring military-to-military dialogue\n\nBeijing is also furious over Washington's deepening defence ties in the Asia-Pacific, particularly with the Philippines, and its regular deployment of warships and fighter jets in the Taiwan Strait and South China Sea.\n\nChina views this as part of a decades-long US effort to contain it.\n\nPresident Joe Biden's administration and China have been stepping up communication to ease friction between the nuclear-armed rivals, with Secretary of State Antony Blinken visiting Beijing and Shanghai last month. A key focus has been the resumption of military-to-military dialogue.\n\nChina scrapped military communications with the United States in 2022 in response to then-US House Speaker Nancy Pelosi's visit to Taiwan.\n\nTensions between Washington and Beijing were stoked further during 2023 by issues including an alleged Chinese spy balloon that was shot down over US airspace, a meeting between Taiwan's then-president Tsai Ing-wen and Pelosi's successor Kevin McCarthy, and American military aid for Taipei.\n\nThe two sides agreed after a summit between Chinese leader Xi Jinping and Biden in November last year to restart high-level military talks.\n\nThat includes a communications channel between the U.S. Indo-Pacific Command chief and Chinese commanders responsible for military operations near Taiwan, Japan and in the South China Sea.\n\nChinese and American forces have had a series of close encounters in the disputed waterway that China claims almost entirely.\n\nMr. Austin warned before Mr. Biden and Mr. Xi agreed to resume military-to-military dialogue that accidents have the potential to spiral out of control, especially in the absence of open lines of communication between American and Chinese forces.\n\nFriday's meeting between Mr. Austin and Mr. Dong follows a phone call between the pair in April, and offers hope of further military talks to cool tensions. The two leaders will give speeches this weekend at the Shangri-La Dialogue in which they are expected to touch on a range of their nations' pressure points.\n\nPressure points\n\nThe U.S., increasingly worried about China's fast-developing military capabilities, has been strengthening its alliances and partnerships in the region to counter China's growing assertiveness over Taiwan and in the South China Sea.\n\nIn a post on X early on Friday announcing his arrival in Singapore, Mr. Austin said he would meet with regional counterparts and continue his department's work with \"like-minded Indo-Pacific partners to promote our shared vision for a free and open region\".\n\nPhilippine President Ferdinand Marcos, who has sought to deepen defence cooperation with the United States as he stands up to Chinese actions in waters off the Southeast Asia country, will deliver the Shangri-La Dialogue's keynote speech on Friday.\n\namj/cwl\n\nRead Comments", "source": {"uri": defence chiefs meet in Singapore", "body": "Police officers stand watch outside Singapore's Shangri-La Hotel on Friday, site of a yearly defence chiefs meeting increasingly seen as a barometer of US-China relations\n\nThe US and Chinese defence chiefs held rare direct talks in Singapore on Friday, offering hopes for more military dialogue that could help prevent disputes over Taiwan and other flashpoint issues from spinning out of control.\n\nThe meeting between the United States' Lloyd Austin and China's Dong Jun on the sidelines of the Shangri-La Dialogue is the first substantive face-to-face talks between the two countries' defence chiefs in 18 months.\n\nDong and Austin began the talks shortly before 1:00 pm (0500 GMT) at the luxury hotel hosting the security forum, a member of the US delegation told reporters.\n\nDefence chiefs and officials from around the world are attending the annual forum that has in recent years become a barometer of US-China relations.\n\nThis year's edition comes a week after China held military drills around Taiwan and warned of war over the US-backed island following the inauguration of President Lai Ching-te, who Beijing has described as a \"dangerous separatist\".\n\nThe dispute over democratic Taiwan, which Beijing considers part of its territory, tops the list of disputes between the rivals.\n\nBeijing is also furious over Washington's deepening defence ties in the Asia-Pacific, particularly with the Philippines, and its regular deployment of warships and fighter jets in the Taiwan Strait and South China Sea.\n\nChina views this as part of a decades-long US effort to contain it.\n\nPresident Joe Biden's administration and China have been stepping up communication to ease friction between the nuclear-armed rivals, with Secretary of State Antony Blinken visiting Beijing and Shanghai last month.\n\nA key focus has been the resumption of military-to-military dialogue.\n\nChina scrapped military communications with the United States in 2022 in response to then-US House Speaker Nancy Pelosi's visit to Taiwan.\n\nTensions between Washington and Beijing were stoked further during 2023 by issues including an alleged Chinese spy balloon that was shot down over US airspace, a meeting between Taiwan's then-president Tsai Ing-wen and Pelosi's successor Kevin McCarthy, and American military aid for Taipei.\n\nThe two sides agreed after a summit between Chinese leader Xi Jinping and Biden in November last year to restart high-level military talks.\n\n- Pressure points -\n\nThat includes a communications channel between the US Indo-Pacific Command chief and Chinese commanders responsible for military operations near Taiwan, Japan and in the South China Sea.\n\nChinese and American forces have had a series of close encounters in the disputed waterway that China claims almost entirely.\n\nAustin warned prior to Biden and Xi agreeing to resume military-to-military dialogue that accidents have the potential to spiral out of control, especially in the absence of open lines of communication between American and Chinese forces.\n\nFriday's meeting between Austin and Dong follows a phone call between the pair in April, and offers hope of further military talks to cool tensions.\n\nAustin and Dong will give speeches this weekend at the Shangri-La Dialogue in which they are expected to touch on a range of their nations' pressure points.\n\nThe United States, increasingly worried about China's fast-developing military capabilities, has been strengthening its alliances and partnerships in the region to counter China's growing assertiveness over Taiwan and in the South China Sea.\n\nIn a post on X early Friday announcing his arrival in Singapore, Austin said he would meet with regional counterparts and continue his department's work with \"like-minded Indo-Pacific partners to promote our shared vision for a free and open region\".\n\nPhilippine President Ferdinand Marcos, who has sought to deepen defence cooperation with the United States as he stands up to Chinese actions in waters off the Southeast Asia country, will deliver the Shangri-La Dialogue's keynote speech on {"uri": "2024-05-374379669", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-31", "time": "11:04:46", "dateTime": "2024-05-31T11:04:46Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-31T11:03:58Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8470588326454163, "url": "https://www.philstar.com/world/2024/05/31/2359429/us-china-resume-military-military-dialogue-coming-months-us-defense-chief", "title": "US-China to resume military-to-military dialogue in 'coming months'  --  US defense chief", "body": "SINGAPORE, Singapore -- The United States and China will resume military-to-military communications \"in the coming months\", US Defense Secretary Lloyd Austin said Friday, as Beijing hailed the \"stabilizing\" security relations between the countries.\n\nAustin met with his Chinese counterpart Dong Jun on the sidelines of the Shangri-La Dialogue in Singapore in the first substantive face-to-face talks between the two defence chiefs in 18 months.\n\nDong and Austin met for over an hour at the luxury hotel hosting the security forum that is attended by defence officials from around the world and in recent years has become a barometer of US-China relations.\n\nAustin said telephone conversations between US and Chinese military commanders would resume \"in the coming months\", according to a readout released by the Pentagon.\n\nHe also welcomed plans for a \"crisis-communications working group\" with China by the end of the year, the statement said.\n\nDescribing the talks as \"positive\", Chinese defence spokesman Wu Qian told reporters that military-to-military relations were \"currently stopping their decline and stabilising\".\n\nBut Wu cautioned that it was not possible for Beijing and Washington to solve all bilateral problems in one meeting, highlighting their thorniest dispute over Taiwan, which China considers part of its territory.\n\nThis year's Shangri-La Dialogue comes a week after China held military drills around self-ruled Taiwan and warned of war over the US-backed island following the inauguration of President Lai Ching-te, who Beijing has described as a \"dangerous separatist\".\n\n\"The Taiwan issue is purely China's internal affairs, external forces have no right to interfere, and the United States' actions seriously violate the one China principle,\" Wu said, referring to Washington's decision to congratulate Lai and send a delegation to the ceremony.\n\nAustin said China's military exercises were \"provocative\" and insisted it should not use Taipei's \"political transition... as a pretext for coercive measures.\"\n\nResuming dialogue\n\nUS President Joe Biden's administration and China have been stepping up communication to ease friction between the nuclear-armed rivals, with Secretary of State Antony Blinken visiting Beijing and Shanghai last month.\n\nA key focus has been the resumption of military-to-military dialogue, which is seen as critical to preventing flashpoint disputes from spinning out of control.\n\nChina scrapped military communications with the United States in 2022 in response to then-US House Speaker Nancy Pelosi's visit to Taiwan.\n\nTensions between Washington and Beijing were further stoked by issues including an alleged Chinese spy balloon that was shot down over US airspace, a meeting between Taiwan's then-president Tsai Ing-wen and Pelosi's successor Kevin McCarthy and American military aid for Taipei.\n\nChina is also furious over the United States' deepening defence ties in the Asia-Pacific, particularly with the Philippines, and its regular deployment of warships and fighter jets in the Taiwan Strait and South China Sea.\n\nBeijing views this as part of a decades-long US effort to contain it.\n\nThe two sides agreed after a summit between Chinese leader Xi Jinping and Biden last November to restart high-level military talks, including over military operations near Taiwan, Japan and in the South China Sea.\n\nPressure points\n\nChinese and American forces have had a series of close encounters in the disputed waterway that China claims almost entirely.\n\nWhile meeting Dong, Austin underscored the importance of \"high seas freedom of navigation\", especially in the South China Sea, and insisted that the United States would continue to \"fly, sail and operate\" wherever international law allowed, the Pentagon readout said.\n\nPhilippine President Ferdinand Marcos, who has sought to deepen defence cooperation with the United States as he stands up to Chinese actions in waters off the Southeast Asia country, will deliver the Shangri-La Dialogue's keynote speech on Friday.\n\nAustin and Dong will also give speeches in Singapore this weekend in which they are expected to touch on a range of their nations' pressure points.\n\nTheir meeting on Friday follows a phone call between them in April, and offers hope of further military talks to cool tensions.\n\nAustin's last significant interaction with a Chinese counterpart was in November 2022 when he met with Wei Fenghe in Cambodia.\n\nWei was subsequently replaced by Li Shangfu, who shook hands and spoke briefly with Austin at the Shangri-La Dialogue in 2023, but they did not hold a formal meeting.", "source": {"uri": "philstar.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Philstar.com"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "8154981212", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-31", "time": "11:04:37", "dateTime": "2024-05-31T11:04:37Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-31T11:04:03Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.843137264251709, "url": "https://www.ibtimes.com/us-china-resume-military-military-dialogue-coming-months-austin-3733312", "title": "US-China To Resume Military-to-military Dialogue In 'Coming Months': Austin", "body": "The United States and China will resume military-to-military communications \"in the coming months\", U.S. Defense Secretary Lloyd Austin said Friday, as Beijing hailed the \"stabilizing\" security relations between the countries.\n\nAustin met with his Chinese counterpart Dong Jun on the sidelines of the Shangri-La Dialogue in Singapore in the first substantive face-to-face talks between the two defense chiefs in 18 months.\n\nDong and Austin met for over an hour at the luxury hotel hosting the security forum that is attended by defence officials from around the world and in recent years has become a barometer of US-China relations.\n\nAustin said telephone conversations between US and Chinese military commanders would resume \"in the coming months\", according to a readout released by the Pentagon.\n\nHe also welcomed plans for a \"crisis-communications working group\" with China by the end of the year, the statement said.\n\nDescribing the talks as \"positive\", Chinese defence spokesman Wu Qian told reporters that military-to-military relations were \"currently stopping their decline and stabilising\".\n\nBut Wu cautioned that it was not possible for Beijing and Washington to solve all bilateral problems in one meeting, highlighting their thorniest dispute over Taiwan, which China considers part of its territory.\n\nThis year's Shangri-La Dialogue comes a week after China held military drills around self-ruled Taiwan and warned of war over the US-backed island following the inauguration of President Lai Ching-te, who Beijing has described as a \"dangerous separatist\".\n\n\"The Taiwan issue is purely China's internal affairs, external forces have no right to interfere, and the United States' actions seriously violate the one China principle,\" Wu said, referring to Washington's decision to congratulate Lai and send a delegation to the ceremony.\n\nAustin said China's military exercises were \"provocative\" and insisted it should not use Taipei's \"political transition... as a pretext for coercive measures.\"\n\nUS President Joe Biden's administration and China have been stepping up communication to ease friction between the nuclear-armed rivals, with Secretary of State Antony Blinken visiting Beijing and Shanghai last month.\n\nA key focus has been the resumption of military-to-military dialogue, which is seen as critical to preventing flashpoint disputes from spinning out of control.\n\nChina scrapped military communications with the United States in 2022 in response to then-US House Speaker Nancy Pelosi's visit to Taiwan.\n\nTensions between Washington and Beijing were further stoked by issues including an alleged Chinese spy balloon that was shot down over US airspace, a meeting between Taiwan's then-president Tsai Ing-wen and Pelosi's successor Kevin McCarthy and American military aid for Taipei.\n\nChina is also furious over the United States' deepening defence ties in the Asia-Pacific, particularly with the Philippines, and its regular deployment of warships and fighter jets in the Taiwan Strait and South China Sea.\n\nBeijing views this as part of a decades-long US effort to contain it.\n\nThe two sides agreed after a summit between Chinese leader Xi Jinping and Biden last November to restart high-level military talks, including over military operations near Taiwan, Japan and in the South China Sea.\n\nChinese and American forces have had a series of close encounters in the disputed waterway that China claims almost entirely.\n\nWhile meeting Dong, Austin underscored the importance of \"high seas freedom of navigation\", especially in the South China Sea, and insisted that the United States would continue to \"fly, sail and operate\" wherever international law allowed, the Pentagon readout said.\n\nPhilippine President Ferdinand Marcos, who has sought to deepen defence cooperation with the United States as he stands up to Chinese actions in waters off the Southeast Asia country, will deliver the Shangri-La Dialogue's keynote speech on Friday.\n\nAustin and Dong will also give speeches in Singapore this weekend in which they are expected to touch on a range of their nations' pressure points.\n\nTheir meeting on Friday follows a phone call between them in April, and offers hope of further military talks to cool tensions.\n\nAustin's last significant interaction with a Chinese counterpart was in November 2022 when he met with Wei Fenghe in Cambodia.\n\nWei was subsequently replaced by Li Shangfu, who shook hands and spoke briefly with Austin at the Shangri-La Dialogue in 2023, but they did not hold a formal meeting.", "source": {"uri": "ibtimes.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "International Business News", "body": "Policemen are seen at the Shangri-La Hotel during the 21st Shangri-La Dialogue summit in Singapore on May 31, 2024.\n\nThe U.S. and Chinese defense chiefs were in Singapore on Friday for a major security forum where they are set to hold rare direct talks, with Taiwan and other flashpoint disputes expected to dominate the three-day event.\n\nThe meeting between the United States' Lloyd Austin and China's Dong Jun on the sidelines of the Shangri-La Dialogue will be the first substantive face-to-face talks between the two countries' defense chiefs in 18 months.\n\nDefense chiefs and officials from around the world are attending the annual forum that has in recent years become a barometer of U.S.-China relations.\n\nThis year's edition comes a week after China held military drills around Taiwan and warned of war over the U.S.-backed island following the inauguration of President Lai Ching-te, who Beijing has described as a \"dangerous separatist\".\n\nThe dispute over democratic Taiwan, which Beijing considers part of its territory, tops the list of disputes between the rivals.\n\nBeijing is also furious over Washington's deepening defense ties in the Asia-Pacific, particularly with the Philippines, and its regular deployment of warships and fighter jets in the Taiwan Strait and South China Sea.\n\nChina views this as part of a decades-long U.S. effort to contain it.\n\nPresident Joe Biden's administration and China have been stepping up communication to ease friction between the nuclear-armed rivals, with Secretary of State Antony Blinken visiting Beijing and Shanghai last month.\n\nA key focus has been the resumption of military-to-military dialogue.\n\nChina scrapped military communications with the United States in 2022 in response to then-U.S. House Speaker Nancy Pelosi's visit to Taiwan.\n\nTensions between Washington and Beijing were stoked further during 2023 by issues including an alleged Chinese spy balloon that was shot down over U.S. airspace, a meeting between Taiwan's then-president Tsai Ing-wen and Pelosi's successor Kevin McCarthy, and American military aid for Taipei.\n\nThe two sides agreed after a summit between Chinese leader Xi Jinping and Biden in November last year to restart high-level military talks.\n\nPressure points\n\nThat includes a communications channel between the U.S. Indo-Pacific Command chief and Chinese commanders responsible for military operations near Taiwan, Japan and in the South China Sea.\n\nChinese and American forces have had a series of close encounters in the disputed waterway that China claims almost entirely.\n\nAustin warned prior to Biden and Xi agreeing to resume military-to-military dialogue that accidents have the potential to spiral out of control, especially in the absence of open lines of communication between American and Chinese forces.\n\nThe highly anticipated meeting between Austin and Dong will follow a phone call between the pair in April, and offer hopes of further military talks to cool tensions.\n\nAustin and Dong will give speeches this weekend at the Shangri-La Dialogue in which they are expected to touch on a range of their nations' pressure points.\n\nThe United States, increasingly worried about China's fast-developing military capabilities, has been strengthening its alliances and partnerships in the region to counter China's growing assertiveness over Taiwan and in the South China Sea.\n\nIn a post on X early Friday announcing his arrival in Singapore, Austin said he would meet with regional counterparts and continue his department's work with \"like-minded Indo-Pacific partners to promote our shared vision for a free and open region\".\n\nPhilippine President Ferdinand Marcos, who has sought to deepen defense "sim": 0.8313725590705872, "url": "https://www.reformer.com/news/national/us-chinese-defence-chiefs-set-to-meet-in-singapore/article_a9c6873f-da07-5779-bf2a-c9dbff3a52e9.html", "title": "US, Chinese defence chiefs set to meet in Singapore", "body": "The US and Chinese defence chiefs were in Singapore on Friday for a major security forum where they are set to hold rare direct talks, with Taiwan and other flashpoint disputes expected to dominate the three-day event.\n\nThe meeting between the United States' Lloyd Austin and China's Dong Jun on the sidelines of the Shangri-La Dialogue will be the first substantive face-to-face talks between the two countries' defence chiefs in 18 months.\n\nDefence chiefs and officials from around the world are attending the annual forum that has in recent years become a barometer of US-China relations.\n\nThis year's edition comes a week after China held military drills around Taiwan and warned of war over the US-backed island following the inauguration of President Lai Ching-te, who Beijing has described as a \"dangerous separatist\".\n\nThe dispute over democratic Taiwan, which Beijing considers part of its territory, tops the list of disputes between the rivals.\n\nBeijing is also furious over Washington's deepening defence ties in the Asia-Pacific, particularly with the Philippines, and its regular deployment of warships and fighter jets in the Taiwan Strait and South China Sea.\n\nChina views this as part of a decades-long US effort to contain it.\n\nPresident Joe Biden's administration and China have been stepping up communication to ease friction between the nuclear-armed rivals, with Secretary of State Antony Blinken visiting Beijing and Shanghai last month.\n\nA key focus has been the resumption of military-to-military dialogue.\n\nChina scrapped military communications with the United States in 2022 in response to then-US House Speaker Nancy Pelosi's visit to Taiwan.\n\nTensions between Washington and Beijing were stoked further during 2023 by issues including an alleged Chinese spy balloon that was shot down over US airspace, a meeting between Taiwan's then-president Tsai Ing-wen and Pelosi's successor Kevin McCarthy, and American military aid for Taipei.\n\nMore from this section Opossum brought to safety after being trapped in traffic Robert De Niro speaks at Biden campaign rally outside Trump trial Taiwan Actor Sentenced for Filming, Distributing Sexual Images of Minor - TaiwanPlus News\n\nThe two sides agreed after a summit between Chinese leader Xi Jinping and Biden in November last year to restart high-level military talks.\n\n- Pressure points -\n\nThat includes a communications channel between the US Indo-Pacific Command chief and Chinese commanders responsible for military operations near Taiwan, Japan and in the South China Sea.\n\nChinese and American forces have had a series of close encounters in the disputed waterway that China claims almost entirely.\n\nAustin warned prior to Biden and Xi agreeing to resume military-to-military dialogue that accidents have the potential to spiral out of control, especially in the absence of open lines of communication between American and Chinese forces.\n\nThe highly anticipated meeting between Austin and Dong will follow a phone call between the pair in April, and offer hopes of further military talks to cool tensions.\n\nAustin and Dong will give speeches this weekend at the Shangri-La Dialogue in which they are expected to touch on a range of their nations' pressure points.\n\nThe United States, increasingly worried about China's fast-developing military capabilities, has been strengthening its alliances and partnerships in the region to counter China's growing assertiveness over Taiwan and in the South China Sea.\n\nIn a post on X early Friday announcing his arrival in Singapore, Austin said he would meet with regional counterparts and continue his department's work with \"like-minded Indo-Pacific partners to promote our shared vision for a free and open region\".\n\nPhilippine President Ferdinand Marcos, who has sought to deepen defence cooperation with the United States as he stands up to Chinese actions in waters off the Southeast Asia country, will deliver the Shangri-La Dialogue's keynote speech on Friday.\n\namj/cwl", "source": {"uri": "reformer.com", months.\n\nDefence chiefs and officials from around the world are attending the annual forum that has in recent years become a barometer of US-China relations.\n\nThis year's edition comes a week after China held military drills around Taiwan and warned of war over the US-backed island following the inauguration of President Lai Ching-te, who Beijing has described as a \"dangerous decades-long US effort to contain it.\n\nPresident Joe Biden's administration and China have been stepping up communication to ease friction between the nuclear-armed rivals, with Secretary of State Taiwan and other flashpoint disputes expected to dominate the three-day event.\n\nThe meeting between the United States' Lloyd Austin and China's Dong Jun on the sidelines of the Shangri-La Dialogue will be the first substantive face-to-face talks between the two countries' defence chiefs in 18 months.\n\nDefence chiefs and officials from around the world are attending the annual forum that has in recent years become a barometer of US-China relations.\n\nThis year's edition comes a week after China held military drills around Taiwan and warned of war over the US-backed island following the inauguration of President Lai Ching-te, who Beijing has described as a \"dangerous separatist\".\n\nThe dispute over democratic Taiwan, which Beijing considers part of its territory, tops the list of disputes between the rivals.\n\nBeijing is also furious over Washington's deepening defence ties in the Asia-Pacific, particularly with the Philippines, and its regular deployment of warships and fighter jets in the Taiwan Strait and South China Sea.\n\nChina views this as part of a decades-long US effort to contain it.\n\nPresident Joe Biden's administration and China have been stepping up communication to ease friction between the nuclear-armed rivals, with Secretary of State Antony Blinken visiting Beijing and Shanghai last month.\n\nA key focus has been the resumption of military-to-military dialogue.\n\nChina scrapped military communications with the United States in 2022 in response to then-US House Speaker Nancy Pelosi's visit to Taiwan.\n\nTensions between Washington and Beijing were stoked further during 2023 by issues including an alleged Chinese spy balloon that was shot down over US airspace, a meeting between Taiwan's then-president Tsai Ing-wen and Pelosi's successor Kevin McCarthy, and American military aid for Taipei.\n\nThe two sides agreed after a summit between Chinese leader Xi Jinping and Biden in November last year to restart high-level military talks.\n\n- Pressure points -\n\nThat includes a communications channel between the US Indo-Pacific Command chief and Chinese commanders responsible for military operations near Taiwan, Japan and in the South China Sea.\n\nChinese and American forces have had a series of close encounters in the disputed waterway that China claims almost entirely.\n\nAustin warned prior to Biden and Xi agreeing to resume military-to-military dialogue that accidents have the potential to spiral out of control, especially in the absence of open lines of communication between American and Chinese forces.\n\nThe highly anticipated meeting between Austin and Dong will follow a phone call between the pair in April, and offer hopes of further military talks to cool tensions.\n\nAustin and Dong will give speeches this weekend at the Shangri-La Dialogue in which they are expected to touch on a range of their nations' pressure points.\n\nThe United States, increasingly worried about China's fast-developing military capabilities, has been strengthening its alliances and partnerships in the region to counter China's growing assertiveness over Taiwan and in the South China Sea.\n\nIn a post on X early Friday announcing his arrival in Singapore, Austin said he would meet with regional counterparts and continue his department's work with \"like-minded Indo-Pacific partners to promote our shared vision for a free and open region\".\n\nPhilippine President Ferdinand Marcos, who has sought to deepen defence cooperation with the United States as he stands up to Chinese actions in waters off the Southeast Asia country, will deliver the Shangri-La Dialogue's keynote speech on Friday.\n\namj/cwl\n\nMore from this section\n\nOnline notarization is streamlined with Secured Signing's new features\n\nRepublican blocks confirmation of first Native American federal judge for Montana\n\nThe 12th Zaragoza Awards Pay Tribute to the Courage, Achievements and "news", "sim": 0.8313725590705872, "url": "https://www.ibtimes.com.au/us-china-resume-military-military-dialogue-coming-months-austin-1848384", "title": "US-China To Resume Military-to-military Dialogue In 'Coming Months': Austin", "body": "The United States and China will resume military-to-military communications \"in the coming months\", US Defense Secretary Lloyd Austin said Friday, as Beijing hailed the \"stabilising\" security relations between the countries.\n\nAustin met with his Chinese counterpart Dong Jun on the sidelines of the Shangri-La Dialogue in Singapore in the first substantive face-to-face talks between the two defence chiefs in 18 months.\n\nDong and Austin met for over an hour at the luxury hotel hosting the security forum that is attended by defence officials from around the world and in recent years has become a barometer of US-China relations.\n\nAustin said telephone conversations between US and Chinese military commanders would resume \"in the coming months\", according to a readout released by the Pentagon.\n\nHe also welcomed plans for a \"crisis-communications working group\" with China by the end of the year, the statement said.\n\nDescribing the talks as \"positive\", Chinese defence spokesman Wu Qian told reporters that military-to-military relations were \"currently stopping their decline and stabilising\".\n\nWu cautioned that it was not possible for Beijing and Washington to solve all bilateral problems in one meeting, but said \"talking is better than not talking\".\n\nThis year's Shangri-La Dialogue comes a week after China held military drills around Taiwan and warned of war over the US-backed island following the inauguration of President Lai Ching-te, who Beijing has described as a \"dangerous separatist\".\n\nSelf-ruled Taiwan, which Beijing considers part of its territory, tops the list of disputes between the rivals.\n\nChina is also furious over the United States' deepening defence ties in the Asia-Pacific, particularly with the Philippines, and its regular deployment of warships and fighter jets in the Taiwan Strait and South China Sea.\n\nBeijing views this as part of a decades-long US effort to contain it.\n\nUS President Joe Biden's administration and China have been stepping up communication to ease friction between the nuclear-armed rivals, with Secretary of State Antony Blinken visiting Beijing and Shanghai last month.\n\nA key focus has been the resumption of military-to-military dialogue, which is seen as critical to preventing flashpoint disputes from spinning out of control.\n\nChina scrapped military communications with the United States in 2022 in response to then-US House Speaker Nancy Pelosi's visit to Taiwan.\n\nTensions between Washington and Beijing were stoked further during 2023 by issues including an alleged Chinese spy balloon that was shot down over US airspace, a meeting between Taiwan's then-president Tsai Ing-wen and Pelosi's successor Kevin McCarthy, and American military aid for Taipei.\n\nThe two sides agreed after a summit between Chinese leader Xi Jinping and Biden last November to restart high-level military talks.\n\nThat includes a communications channel between the US Indo-Pacific Command chief and Chinese commanders responsible for military operations near Taiwan, Japan and in the South China Sea.\n\nChinese and American forces have had a series of close encounters in the disputed waterway that China claims almost entirely.\n\nAustin warned prior to Biden and Xi agreeing to resume military-to-military dialogue that accidents have the potential to spiral out of control, especially in the absence of open lines of communication between American and Chinese forces.\n\nFriday's meeting between Austin and Dong follows a phone call between the pair in April, and offers hope of further military talks to cool tensions.\n\nAustin's last significant interaction with a Chinese counterpart was in November 2022 when he met with Wei Fenghe in Cambodia.\n\nWei was subsequently replaced by Li Shangfu, who shook hands and spoke briefly with Austin at the Shangri-La Dialogue in 2023 but did not hold a formal meeting with him.\n\nAustin and Dong will give speeches this weekend at the Shangri-La Dialogue in which they are expected to touch on a range of their nations' pressure points.\n\nThe United States, increasingly worried about China's fast-developing military capabilities, has been strengthening its alliances and partnerships in the region to counter China's growing assertiveness over Taiwan and in the South China Sea.\n\nIn the meeting, Austin underscored the United States' commitment to the one China policy, but insisted that it would continue to \"fly, sail and operate\" wherever international law allowed, the Pentagon readout said.\n\nPhilippine President Ferdinand Marcos, who has sought to deepen defence cooperation with the United States as he stands "title": "US-China to resume military-to-military dialogue in 'coming months': Austin", "body": "Policemen are seen at the Shangri-La Hotel during the 21st Shangri-La Dialogue summit in Singapore\n\nThe United States and China will resume military-to-military communications \"in the coming months\", US Defense Secretary Lloyd Austin said Friday, as Beijing hailed the \"stabilising\" security relations between the countries.\n\nAustin met with his Chinese counterpart Dong Jun on the sidelines of the Shangri-La Dialogue in Singapore in the first substantive face-to-face talks between the two defence chiefs in 18 months.\n\nDong and Austin met for over an hour at the luxury hotel hosting the security forum that is attended by defence officials from around the world and in recent years has become a barometer of US-China relations.\n\nAustin said telephone conversations between US and Chinese military commanders would resume \"in the coming months\", according to a readout released by the Pentagon.\n\nHe also welcomed plans for a \"crisis-communications working group\" with China by the end of the year, the statement said.\n\nDescribing the talks as \"positive\", Chinese defence spokesman Wu Qian told reporters that military-to-military relations were \"currently stopping their decline and stabilising\".\n\nWu cautioned that it was not possible for Beijing and Washington to solve all bilateral problems in one meeting, but said \"talking is better than not talking\".\n\nThis year's Shangri-La Dialogue comes a week after China held military drills around Taiwan and warned of war over the US-backed island following the inauguration of President Lai Ching-te, who Beijing has described as a \"dangerous separatist\".\n\nSelf-ruled Taiwan, which Beijing considers part of its territory, tops the list of disputes between the rivals.\n\nChina is also furious over the United States' deepening defence ties in the Asia-Pacific, particularly with the Philippines, and its regular deployment of warships and fighter jets in the Taiwan Strait and South China Sea.\n\nBeijing views this as part of a decades-long US effort to contain it.\n\nUS President Joe Biden's administration and China have been stepping up communication to ease friction between the nuclear-armed rivals, with Secretary of State Antony Blinken visiting Beijing and Shanghai last month.\n\nA key focus has been the resumption of military-to-military dialogue, which is seen as critical to preventing flashpoint disputes from spinning out of control.\n\nChina scrapped military communications with the United States in 2022 in response to then-US House Speaker Nancy Pelosi's visit to Taiwan.\n\nTensions between Washington and Beijing were stoked further during 2023 by issues including an alleged Chinese spy balloon that was shot down over US airspace, a meeting between Taiwan's then-president Tsai Ing-wen and Pelosi's successor Kevin McCarthy, and American military aid for Taipei.\n\nThe two sides agreed after a summit between Chinese leader Xi Jinping and Biden last November to restart high-level military talks.\n\nThat includes a communications channel between the US Indo-Pacific Command chief and Chinese commanders responsible for military operations near Taiwan, Japan and in the South China Sea.\n\n- Pressure points -\n\nChinese and American forces have had a series of close encounters in the disputed waterway that China claims almost entirely.\n\nAustin warned prior to Biden and Xi agreeing to resume military-to-military dialogue that accidents have the potential to spiral out of control, especially in the absence of open lines of communication between American and Chinese forces.\n\nFriday's meeting between Austin and Dong follows a phone call between the pair in April, and offers hope of further military talks to cool tensions.\n\nAustin's last significant interaction with a Chinese counterpart was in November 2022 when he met with Wei Fenghe in Cambodia.\n\nWei was subsequently replaced by Li Shangfu, who shook hands and spoke briefly with Austin at the Shangri-La Dialogue in 2023 but did not hold a formal meeting with him.\n\nAustin and Dong will give speeches this weekend at the Shangri-La Dialogue in which they are expected to touch on a range of their nations' pressure points.\n\nThe United States, increasingly worried about China's fast-developing military capabilities, has been strengthening its alliances and partnerships in the region to counter China's growing assertiveness over Taiwan and in the South China Sea.\n\nIn the meeting, Austin underscored the United States' commitment to the one China policy, but insisted that it would continue to \"fly, sail and operate\" wherever international law allowed, the Pentagon readout said.\n\nPhilippine President Ferdinand Marcos, who has sought to deepen defence cooperation with the United States as he stands up to Chinese actions in waters off the Southeast Asia country, will deliver the Shangri-La Dialogue's keynote speech on Friday.\n\nbur-amj/dhw", "source": {"uri": "ktbs.com", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8274509906768799, "url": "https://www.spacewar.com/afp/240531094654.calxst2p.html", "title": "US-China to resume military-to-military dialogue in 'coming months': Austin", "body": "Austin met with his Chinese counterpart Dong Jun on the sidelines of the Shangri-La Dialogue in Singapore in the first substantive face-to-face talks between the two defence chiefs in 18 months.\n\nDong and Austin met for over an hour at the luxury hotel hosting the security forum that is attended by defence officials from around the world and in recent years has become a barometer of US-China relations.\n\nAustin said telephone conversations between US and Chinese military commanders would resume \"in the coming months\", according to a readout released by the Pentagon.\n\nHe also welcomed plans for a \"crisis-communications working group\" with China by the end of the year, the statement said.\n\nDescribing the talks as \"positive\", Chinese defence spokesman Wu Qian told reporters that military-to-military relations were \"currently stopping their decline and stabilising\".\n\nBut Wu cautioned that it was not possible for Beijing and Washington to solve all bilateral problems in one meeting, highlighting their thorniest dispute over Taiwan, which China considers part of its territory.\n\nThis year's Shangri-La Dialogue comes a week after China held military drills around self-ruled Taiwan and warned of war over the US-backed island following the inauguration of President Lai Ching-te, who Beijing has described as a \"dangerous separatist\".\n\n\"The Taiwan issue is purely China's internal affairs, external forces have no right to interfere, and the United States' actions seriously violate the one China principle,\" Wu said, referring to Washington's decision to congratulate Lai and send a delegation to the ceremony.\n\nAustin said China's military exercises were \"provocative\" and insisted it should not use Taipei's \"political transition... as a pretext for coercive measures.\"\n\nUS President Joe Biden's administration and China have been stepping up communication to ease friction between the nuclear-armed rivals, with Secretary of State Antony Blinken visiting Beijing and Shanghai last month.\n\nA key focus has been the resumption of military-to-military dialogue, which is seen as critical to preventing flashpoint disputes from spinning out of control.\n\nChina scrapped military communications with the United States in 2022 in response to then-US House Speaker Nancy Pelosi's visit to Taiwan.\n\nTensions between Washington and Beijing were further stoked by issues including an alleged Chinese spy balloon that was shot down over US airspace, a meeting between Taiwan's then-president Tsai Ing-wen and Pelosi's successor Kevin McCarthy warships and fighter jets in the Taiwan Strait and South China Sea.\n\nBeijing views this as part of a decades-long US effort to contain it.\n\nThe two sides agreed after a summit between Chinese leader Xi Jinping and Biden last November to restart high-level military talks, including over military operations near Taiwan, Japan and in the South China Sea.\n\nChinese and American forces have had a series of close encounters in the disputed waterway that China claims almost entirely.\n\nWhile meeting Dong, Austin underscored the importance of \"high seas freedom of navigation\", especially {"uri": "8154331915", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-31", "time": "03:01:37", "dateTime": "2024-05-31T03:01:37Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-31T03:01:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8274509906768799, "url": "https://www.spacewar.com/afp/240531023423.lm46bhoh.html", "title": "US, Chinese defence chiefs set to meet in Singapore", "body": "The meeting between the United States' Lloyd Austin and China's Dong Jun on the sidelines of the Shangri-La Dialogue will be the first substantive face-to-face talks between the two countries' defence chiefs in 18 months.\n\nDefence chiefs and officials from around the world are attending the annual forum that has in recent years become a barometer of US-China relations.\n\nThis year's edition comes a week after China held military drills around Taiwan and warned of war over the US-backed island following the inauguration of President Lai Ching-te, who Beijing has described as a \"dangerous separatist\".\n\nThe dispute over democratic Taiwan, which Beijing considers part of its territory, tops the list of disputes between the rivals.\n\nBeijing is also furious over Washington's deepening defence ties in the Asia-Pacific, particularly with the Philippines, and its regular deployment of warships and fighter jets in the Taiwan Strait and South China Sea.\n\nChina views this as part of a decades-long US effort to contain it.\n\nPresident Joe Biden's administration and China have been stepping up communication to ease friction between the nuclear-armed rivals, with Secretary of State Antony Blinken visiting Beijing and Shanghai last month.\n\nA key focus has been the resumption of military-to-military dialogue.\n\nChina scrapped military communications with the United States in 2022 in response to then-US House Speaker Nancy Pelosi's visit to Taiwan.\n\nTensions between Washington and Beijing were stoked further during 2023 by issues including an alleged Chinese spy balloon that was shot down over US airspace, a meeting between Taiwan's then-president Tsai Ing-wen and Pelosi's successor Kevin McCarthy, and American military aid for Taipei.\n\nThe two sides agreed after a summit between Chinese leader Xi Jinping and Biden in November last year to restart high-level military talks.\n\nThat includes a communications channel between the US Indo-Pacific Command chief and Chinese commanders responsible for military operations near Taiwan, Japan and in the South China Sea.\n\nChinese and American forces have had a series of close encounters in the disputed waterway that China claims almost entirely.\n\nAustin warned prior to Biden and Xi agreeing to resume military-to-military dialogue that accidents have the potential to spiral out of control, especially in the absence of open lines of communication between American and Chinese forces.\n\nThe highly anticipated meeting between Austin and Dong will follow a phone call between the pair in April, and offer hopes of further military talks to cool tensions.\n\nAustin and Dong will give speeches this weekend at the Shangri-La Dialogue in which they are expected to touch on a range of their nations' pressure points.\n\nThe United States, increasingly worried about China's fast-developing military capabilities, has been strengthening its alliances and partnerships in the region to counter China's growing assertiveness over Taiwan and in the South China Sea.\n\nIn a post on X early Friday announcing his arrival in Singapore, Austin said he would meet with regional counterparts and continue his department's work with \"like-minded Indo-Pacific partners to promote our shared vision for a free and open region\".\n\nPhilippine President Ferdinand Marcos, who has sought to deepen defence "sim": 0.8235294222831726, "url": "https://www.spacewar.com/afp/240531081138.5sl2xt06.html", "title": "US-China to resume military-to-military dialogue in 'coming months': Austin", "body": "Austin met with his Chinese counterpart Dong Jun on the sidelines of the Shangri-La Dialogue in Singapore in the first substantive face-to-face talks between the two defence chiefs in 18 months.\n\nDong and Austin met for over an hour at the luxury hotel hosting the security forum that is attended by defence officials from around the world and in recent years has become a barometer of US-China relations.\n\nAustin said telephone conversations between US and Chinese military commanders would resume \"in the coming months\", according to a readout released by the Pentagon.\n\nHe also welcomed plans for a \"crisis-communications working group\" with China by the end of the year, the statement said.\n\nDescribing the talks as \"positive\", Chinese defence spokesman Wu Qian told reporters that military-to-military relations were \"currently stopping their decline and stabilising\".\n\nWu cautioned that it was not possible for Beijing and Washington to solve all bilateral problems in one meeting, but said \"talking is better than not talking\".\n\nThis year's Shangri-La Dialogue comes a week after China held military drills around Taiwan and warned of war over the US-backed island following the inauguration of President Lai Ching-te, who Beijing has described as a \"dangerous separatist\".\n\nSelf-ruled Taiwan, which Beijing considers part of its territory, tops the list of disputes between the rivals.\n\nChina is also furious over the United States' deepening defence ties in the Asia-Pacific, particularly with the Philippines, and its regular deployment of warships and fighter jets in the Taiwan Strait and South China Sea.\n\nBeijing views this as part of a decades-long US effort to contain it.\n\nUS President Joe Biden's administration and China have been stepping up communication to ease friction between the nuclear-armed rivals, with Secretary of State Antony Blinken visiting Beijing and Shanghai last month.\n\nA key focus has been the resumption of military-to-military dialogue, which is seen as critical to preventing flashpoint disputes from spinning out of control.\n\nChina scrapped military communications with the United States in 2022 in response to then-US House Speaker Nancy Pelosi's visit to Taiwan.\n\nTensions between Washington and Beijing were stoked further during 2023 by issues including an alleged Chinese spy balloon that was shot down over US airspace, a meeting between Taiwan's then-president Tsai Ing-wen and Pelosi's successor Kevin McCarthy, and American military aid for Taipei.\n\nThe two sides agreed after a summit between Chinese leader Xi Jinping and Biden last November to restart high-level military talks.\n\nThat includes a communications channel between the US Indo-Pacific Command chief and Chinese commanders responsible for military operations near Taiwan, Japan and in the South China Sea.\n\nChinese and American forces have had a series of close encounters in the disputed waterway that China claims almost entirely.\n\nAustin warned prior to Biden and Xi agreeing to resume military-to-military dialogue that accidents have the potential to spiral out of control, especially in the absence of open lines of communication between American and Chinese forces.\n\nFriday's meeting between Austin and Dong follows a phone call between the pair in April, and offers hope of further military talks to cool tensions.\n\nAustin's last significant interaction with a Chinese counterpart was in November 2022 when he met with Wei Fenghe in Cambodia.\n\nWei was subsequently replaced by Li Shangfu, who shook hands and spoke briefly with Austin at the Shangri-La Dialogue in 2023 but did not hold a formal meeting with him.\n\nAustin and Dong will give speeches this weekend at the Shangri-La Dialogue in which they are expected to touch on a range of their nations' pressure points.\n\nThe United States, increasingly worried about China's fast-developing military capabilities, has been strengthening its alliances and partnerships in the region to counter China's growing assertiveness over Taiwan and in the South China Sea.\n\nIn the meeting, Austin underscored the United States' commitment to the one China policy, but insisted that it would continue to \"fly, sail and operate\" wherever international law allowed, the Pentagon readout said.\n\nPhilippine President Ferdinand Marcos, who has sought to deepen defence cooperation with the United States as he stands up to Chinese actions in waters off the Southeast Asia country, will deliver the Shangri-La Dialogue's keynote speech on The meeting followed a video conference call in April.\n\nDefence chiefs and officials from around the world are attending the annual forum that has in recent years become a barometer of US-China relations.\n\nThis year's edition comes a week after China held military drills around Taiwan and warned of war over the US-backed island following the inauguration of President William Lai Ching-te, who Beijing has described as a \"dangerous separatist\".\n\nThe dispute over democratic Taiwan, which Beijing considers part of its territory, tops the list of disagreements between the rivals.\n\nBeijing is furious over Washington's deepening defence ties in the Asia Pacific, particularly with the Philippines, and its regular deployment of warships and fighter jets in the Taiwan Strait and South China Sea.\n\nIn recent weeks, the Philippines hosted the largest ever joint military exercise with the US. On Thursday, China's defence ministry strongly condemned the deployment of a US intermediate-range missile system in the northern Philippines during military drills in April, saying it \"brought huge risks of war into the region\".\n\nChina views the activities as part of a decades-long US effort to contain it.\n\nPresident Joe Biden's administration and China have been stepping up communication to ease friction between the nuclear-armed rivals, with Secretary of State Antony Blinken visiting Beijing and Shanghai last month.\n\nA key focus has been the resumption of military-to-military dialogue.\n\nChina scrapped military communications with the United States in 2022 in response to then-US House Speaker Nancy Pelosi's visit to Taiwan.\n\nTensions between Washington and Beijing were stoked further during 2023 by issues including an alleged Chinese spy balloon that was shot down over US airspace, a meeting between Taiwan's then-president Tsai Ing-wen and Pelosi's successor Kevin McCarthy, and American military aid for Taipei.\n\nThe two sides agreed after a summit between Chinese leader Xi Jinping and Biden in November last year to restart high-level military talks.\n\nThat includes a communications channel between the US Asia Pacific command chief and Chinese commanders responsible for military operations near Taiwan, Japan and in the South China Sea.\n\nChinese and US forces have had a series of close encounters in the disputed waterway that China claims almost entirely.\n\nAustin warned prior to Biden and Xi agreeing to resume military-to-military dialogue that accidents have the potential to spiral out of control, especially in the absence of open lines of communication between American and Chinese forces.\n\nIn a post on X early on Friday announcing his {"uri": "8154810865", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-31", "time": "09:18:39", "dateTime": "2024-05-31T09:18:39Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-31T09:17:49Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8117647171020508, "url": "https://www.reformer.com/news/national/us-china-to-resume-military-to-military-dialogue-in-coming-months-austin/article_a9c6873f-da07-5779-bf2a-c9dbff3a52e9.html", "title": "US-China to resume military-to-military dialogue in 'coming months': Austin", "body": "Policemen are seen at the Shangri-La Hotel during the 21st Shangri-La Dialogue summit in Singapore\n\nThe United States and China will resume military-to-military communications \"in the coming months\", US Defense Secretary Lloyd Austin said Friday, as Beijing hailed the \"stabilising\" security relations between the countries.\n\nAustin met with his Chinese counterpart Dong Jun on the sidelines of the Shangri-La Dialogue in Singapore in the first substantive face-to-face talks between the two defence chiefs in 18 months.\n\nDong and Austin met for over an hour at the luxury hotel hosting the security forum that is attended by defence officials from around the world and in recent years has become a barometer of US-China relations.\n\nAustin said telephone conversations between US and Chinese military commanders would resume \"in the coming months\", according to a readout released by the Pentagon.\n\nHe also welcomed plans for a \"crisis-communications working group\" with China by the end of the year, the statement said.\n\nDescribing the talks as \"positive\", Chinese defence spokesman Wu Qian told reporters that military-to-military relations were \"currently stopping their decline and stabilising\".\n\nWu cautioned that it was not possible for Beijing and Washington to solve all bilateral problems in one meeting, but said \"talking is better than not talking\".\n\nThis year's Shangri-La Dialogue comes a week after China held military drills around Taiwan and warned of war over the US-backed island following the inauguration of President Lai Ching-te, who Beijing has described as a \"dangerous separatist\".\n\nSelf-ruled Taiwan, which Beijing considers part of its territory, tops the list of disputes between the rivals.\n\nChina is also furious over the United States' deepening defence ties in the Asia-Pacific, particularly with the Philippines, and its regular deployment of warships and fighter jets in the Taiwan Strait and South China Sea.\n\nBeijing views this as part of a decades-long US effort to contain it.\n\nUS President Joe Biden's administration and China have been stepping up communication to ease friction between the nuclear-armed rivals, with Secretary of State Antony Blinken visiting Beijing and Shanghai last month.\n\nA key focus has been the resumption of military-to-military dialogue, which is seen as critical to preventing flashpoint disputes from spinning out of control.\n\nChina scrapped military communications with the United States in 2022 in response to then-US House Speaker Nancy Pelosi's visit to Taiwan.\n\nMore from this section Fed Reserve President Kashkari Wants 'Many More Months' of Inflation Progress Before Cutting Rates Putin Declares Zelensky's Rule Illegitimate, Asserts Ukrainian Parliament Sole Authority Menendez bribery trial: Jurors see texts sent between senator and wife regarding Egyptian military aid\n\nTensions between Washington and Beijing were stoked further during 2023 by issues including an alleged Chinese spy balloon that was shot down over US airspace, a meeting between Taiwan's then-president Tsai Ing-wen and Pelosi's successor Kevin McCarthy, and American military aid for Taipei.\n\nThe two sides agreed after a summit between Chinese leader Xi Jinping and Biden last November to restart high-level military talks.\n\nThat includes a communications channel between the US Indo-Pacific Command chief and Chinese commanders responsible for military operations near Taiwan, Japan and in the South China Sea.\n\n- Pressure points -\n\nChinese and American forces have had a series of close encounters in the disputed waterway that China claims almost entirely.\n\nAustin warned prior to Biden and Xi agreeing to resume military-to-military dialogue that accidents have the potential to spiral out of control, especially in the absence of open lines of communication between American and Chinese forces.\n\nFriday's meeting between Austin and Dong follows a phone call between the pair in April, and offers hope of further military talks to cool tensions.\n\nAustin's last significant interaction with a Chinese counterpart was in November 2022 when he met with Wei Fenghe in Cambodia.\n\nWei was subsequently replaced by Li Shangfu, who shook hands and spoke briefly with Austin at the Shangri-La Dialogue in 2023 but did not hold a formal meeting with him.\n\nAustin and Dong will give speeches this weekend at the Shangri-La Dialogue in which they are expected to touch on a range of their nations' pressure points.\n\nThe United States, increasingly worried about China's fast-developing military capabilities, has been strengthening its alliances and partnerships in the region to counter China's growing assertiveness over Taiwan and in the South China Sea.\n\nIn the meeting, Austin underscored the United States' commitment to the one China policy, but insisted that it would continue to \"fly, sail and operate\" wherever international law allowed, the Pentagon readout said.\n\nPhilippine President Ferdinand Marcos, who has sought to deepen defence cooperation with the United States as he stands up to Chinese actions in waters off the Southeast Asia country, will deliver the Shangri-La Dialogue's keynote speech on Friday.\n\nbur-amj/dhw", "source": {"uri": "reformer.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Brattleboro Reformer"}, "authors": [{"uri": military-to-military dialogue in 'coming months': Austin", "body": "Policemen are seen at the Shangri-La Hotel during the 21st Shangri-La Dialogue summit in Singapore\n\nThe United States and China will resume military-to-military communications \"in the coming months\", US Defense Secretary Lloyd Austin said Friday, as Beijing hailed the \"stabilising\" security relations between the countries.\n\nAustin met with his Chinese counterpart Dong Jun on the sidelines of the Shangri-La Dialogue in Singapore in the first substantive face-to-face talks between the two defence chiefs in 18 months.\n\nDong and Austin met for over an hour at the luxury hotel hosting the security forum that is attended by defence officials from around the world and in recent years has become a barometer of US-China relations.\n\nAustin said telephone conversations between US and Chinese military commanders would resume \"in the coming months\", according to a readout released by the Pentagon.\n\nHe also welcomed plans for a \"crisis-communications working group\" with China by the end of the year, the statement said.\n\nDescribing the talks as \"positive\", Chinese defence spokesman Wu Qian told reporters that military-to-military relations were \"currently stopping their decline and stabilising\".\n\nWu cautioned that it was not possible for Beijing and Washington to solve all bilateral problems in one meeting, but said \"talking is better than not talking\".\n\nThis year's Shangri-La Dialogue comes a week after China held military drills around Taiwan and warned of war over the US-backed island following the inauguration of President Lai Ching-te, who Beijing has described as a \"dangerous separatist\".\n\nSelf-ruled Taiwan, which Beijing considers part of its territory, tops the list of disputes between the rivals.\n\nChina is also furious over the United States' deepening defence ties in the Asia-Pacific, particularly with the Philippines, and its regular deployment of warships and fighter jets in the Taiwan Strait and South China Sea.\n\nBeijing views this as part of a decades-long US effort to contain it.\n\nUS President Joe Biden's administration and China have been stepping up communication to ease friction between the nuclear-armed rivals, with Secretary of State Antony Blinken visiting Beijing and Shanghai last month.\n\nA key focus has been the resumption of military-to-military dialogue, which is seen as critical to preventing flashpoint disputes from spinning out of control.\n\nChina scrapped military communications with the United States in 2022 in response to then-US House Speaker Nancy Pelosi's visit to Taiwan.\n\nTensions between Washington and Beijing were stoked further during 2023 by issues including an alleged Chinese spy balloon that was shot down over US airspace, a meeting between Taiwan's then-president Tsai Ing-wen and Pelosi's successor Kevin McCarthy, and American military aid for Taipei.\n\nThe two sides agreed after a summit between Chinese leader Xi Jinping and Biden last November to restart high-level military talks.\n\nThat includes a communications channel between the US Indo-Pacific Command chief and Chinese commanders responsible for military operations near Taiwan, Japan and in the South China Sea.\n\n- Pressure points -\n\nChinese and American forces have had a series of close encounters in the disputed waterway that China claims almost entirely.\n\nAustin warned prior to Biden and Xi agreeing to resume military-to-military dialogue that accidents have the potential to spiral out of control, especially in the absence of open lines of communication between American and Chinese forces.\n\nFriday's meeting between Austin and Dong follows a phone call between the pair in April, and offers hope of further military talks to cool tensions.\n\nAustin's last significant interaction with a Chinese counterpart was in November 2022 when he met with Wei Fenghe in Cambodia.\n\nWei was subsequently replaced by Li Shangfu, who shook hands and spoke briefly with Austin at the Shangri-La Dialogue in 2023 but did not hold a formal meeting with him.\n\nAustin and Dong will give speeches this weekend at the Shangri-La Dialogue in which they are expected to touch on a range of their nations' pressure points.\n\nThe United States, increasingly worried about China's fast-developing military capabilities, has been strengthening its alliances and partnerships in the region to counter China's growing assertiveness over Taiwan and in the South China Sea.\n\nIn the meeting, Austin underscored the United States' commitment to the one China policy, but insisted that it would continue to \"fly, sail and operate\" wherever international law allowed, the Pentagon readout said.\n\nPhilippine President Ferdinand Marcos, who has sought to deepen defence cooperation with the United States as he stands up to Chinese actions in waters off the Southeast Asia country, will deliver the Shangri-La Dialogue's keynote speech on Friday.\n\nbur-amj/dhw\n\nMore from this section\n\nACES Quality Management Partners with Digilytics, Provider of AI-Powered Document Indexing, "news", "sim": 0.8039215803146362, "url": "https://www.fox28spokane.com/us-chinese-defence-chiefs-set-to-meet-in-singapore/", "title": "US, Chinese defence chiefs set to meet in Singapore", "body": "The US and Chinese defence chiefs were in Singapore on Friday for a major security forum where they are set to hold rare direct talks, with Taiwan and other flashpoint disputes expected to dominate the three-day event.\n\nThe meeting between the United States' Lloyd Austin and China's Dong Jun on the sidelines of the Shangri-La Dialogue will be the first substantive face-to-face talks between their countries' defence chiefs in 18 months.\n\nDefence chiefs and officials from around the world are attending the annual forum that has in recent years become a barometer of US-China relations.\n\nThis year's edition comes a week after China held military drills around Taiwan and warned of war over the US-backed island following the inauguration of President Lai Ching-te, who Beijing has described as a \"dangerous separatist\".\n\nThe dispute over democratic Taiwan, which Beijing considers part of its territory, tops the list of disputes between the rivals.\n\nBeijing is also furious over Washington's deepening defence ties in the Asia-Pacific, particularly with the Philippines, and its regular deployment of warships and fighter jets in the Taiwan Strait and South China Sea.\n\nChina views this as part of a decades-long US effort to contain it.\n\nPresident Joe Biden's administration and China have been stepping up communication to ease friction between the nuclear-armed rivals, with Secretary of State Antony Blinken visiting Beijing and Shanghai last month.\n\nA key focus has been the resumption of military-to-military dialogue.\n\nChina scrapped military communications with the United States in 2022 in response to then-US House Speaker Nancy Pelosi's visit to Taiwan.\n\nTensions between Washington and Beijing were stoked further during 2023 by issues including an alleged Chinese spy balloon that was shot down over US airspace, a meeting between Taiwan's then president Tsai Ing-wen and Pelosi's successor Kevin McCarthy, and American military aid for Taipei.\n\nThe two sides agreed after a summit between Chinese leader Xi Jinping and Biden in November last year to restart high-level military talks.\n\nThat includes a communications channel between the US Indo-Pacific Command chief and China's commanders responsible for military operations near Taiwan, Japan and in the South China Sea.\n\nChinese and American forces have had a series of close encounters in the disputed waterway that China claims almost entirely.\n\nAustin warned prior to Biden and Xi agreeing to resume military-to-military dialogue that accidents have the potential to spiral out of control, especially in the absence of open lines of communication between American and Chinese forces.\n\nThe meeting between Austin and Dong followed a phone call between the pair in April, and offered hopes of further military talks.\n\namj/cwl\n\nFOX28 Spokane\u00a9", "source": {"uri": "fox28spokane.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "FOX 28 {"uri": "2024-05-374224790", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-31", "time": "08:52:17", "dateTime": "2024-05-31T08:52:17Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-31T08:46:24Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7803921699523926, "url": "https://indianexpress.com/article/world/us-china-defence-chiefs-taiwan-asia-security-summit-9363462/", "title": "US, China defence chiefs lock horns on Taiwan at Asia security summit | World News - The Indian Express", "body": "US Defense Secretary Lloyd Austin and China's defence minister, Dong Jun, met in Singapore on the sidelines of Asia's premier defence summit, the Shangri-La Dialogue.\n\nThe US and Chinese defence chiefs locked horns on Taiwan in their first face-to-face meeting in two years on Friday, but both sides emphasised the need to keep military-to-military communications open.\n\nUS Defense Secretary Lloyd Austin and China's defence minister, Dong Jun, met in Singapore on the sidelines of Asia's premier defence summit, the Shangri-La Dialogue.\n\nThe Philippines' president was to give a speech at the meeting later in the day that was expected to touch on sensitive South China Sea claims.\n\nThe US-China relationship is expected to loom over the dialogue, as are the wars in Ukraine and Gaza, and the South China Sea tensions.\n\nDuring the meeting with Dong, Austin expressed concern about Chinese military activity near Taiwan, including after the island's presidential election and the inauguration of President Lai Ching-te this month, US Air Force Major General Patrick Ryder said in a statement.\n\n\"The secretary expressed concern about recent provocative PLA activity around the Taiwan Strait, and he reiterated that the PRC should not use Taiwan's political transition - part of a normal, routine democratic process - as a pretext for coercive measures,\" Ryder said after the 75-minute meeting.\n\nHe was referring to the People's Liberation Army and the People's Republic of China.\n\nDong warned Austin that the US should not interfere in China's affairs with Taiwan, defence ministry spokesperson Wu Qian told reporters.\n\nThe US approach to Taiwan violates commitments made by the United States and sends the wrong signal to \"separatist forces\" in Taiwan, the spokesperson quoted Dong as saying. Beijing calls Lai a \"separatist\".\n\nBoth sides, however, emphasised the importance of keeping military-to-military ties open, and a senior US defence official, speaking on condition of anonymity, said the meeting marked an \"important step\" in opening lines of communication.\n\nThe official said Austin was \"firm but professional\" and also brought up China's nuclear, space and cyber developments.\n\nThe two sides also discussed the South China Sea and the conflicts in Ukraine and Gaza.\n\nLater on Friday the spotlight shifts to Philippine President Ferdinand R. Marcos Jr, who is expected to discuss the legal and geopolitical position of the Philippines on the South China Sea and note the importance of the waterway to global trade.\n\nChina claims sovereignty over almost all of the South China Sea, including parts claimed by the Philippines, Brunei, Malaysia, Taiwan and Vietnam, despite a 2016 ruling by the Hague-based Permanent Court of Arbitration that found Beijing's sweeping claims have no legal basis.\n\nTaiwan's Defence Minister Wellington Koo told reporters in Taipei on Friday that increased tensions around the democratically governed island claimed by China as its own territory would diminish if Beijing's military drills ceased.\n\n\"If China stops its provocation and intimidation then peace and stability can be maintained,\" he said.\n\nThe region has seen a sharp uptick in such exercises in recent years, according to a report by the London-based International Institute of Strategic Studies (IISS) released on Friday.\n\nAlthough both the United States and China have significantly increased the volume of military exercises across Asia, Beijing's drills still lag in scale and complexity, the study found.\n\nThe Shangri-La Dialogue, in its 21st iteration, is held every year in Singapore by IISS, gathering military and political leaders to discuss security issues. {"uri": "8154806214", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-31", "time": "09:15:47", "dateTime": "2024-05-31T09:15:47Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-31T09:15:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.772549033164978, "url": "https://www.bssnews.net/international/192344", "title": "US-China to resume military-to-military dialogue in 'coming months': Austin | International", "body": "SINGAPORE, May 31, 2024 (BSS/AFP) - The United States and China will resume military-to-military communications \"in the coming months\", US Defense Secretary Lloyd Austin said Friday, as Beijing hailed the \"stabilising\" security relations between the countries.\n\nAustin met with his Chinese counterpart Dong Jun on the sidelines of the Shangri-La Dialogue in Singapore in the first substantive face-to-face talks between the two defence chiefs in 18 months.\n\nDong and Austin met for over an hour at the luxury hotel hosting the security forum that is attended by defence officials from around the world and in recent years has become a barometer of US-China relations.\n\nAustin said telephone conversations between US and Chinese military commanders would resume \"in the coming months\", according to a readout released by the Pentagon.\n\nHe also welcomed plans for a \"crisis-communications working group\" with China by the end of the year, the statement said.\n\nDescribing the talks as \"positive\", Chinese defence spokesman Wu Qian told reporters that military-to-military relations were \"currently stopping their decline and stabilising\".\n\nWu cautioned that it was not possible for Beijing and Washington to solve all bilateral problems in one meeting, but said \"talking is better than not talking\".\n\nUS President Joe Biden's administration and China have been stepping up communication to ease friction between the nuclear-armed rivals, with Secretary of State Antony Blinken visiting Beijing and Shanghai last month.\n\nA key focus has been the resumption of military-to-military dialogue, which is seen as critical to preventing flashpoint disputes from spinning out of control.\n\nChina scrapped military communications with the United States in 2022 in response to then-US House Speaker Nancy Pelosi's visit to Taiwan.\n\nTensions between Washington and Beijing were stoked further during 2023 by issues including an alleged Chinese spy balloon that was shot down over US airspace, a meeting between Taiwan's then-president Tsai Ing-wen and Pelosi's successor Kevin McCarthy, and American military aid for Taipei.\n\nThe two sides agreed after a summit between Chinese leader Xi Jinping and Biden last November to restart high-level military talks.\n\nThat includes a communications channel between the US Indo-Pacific Command chief and Chinese commanders responsible for military operations near Taiwan, Japan and in the South China Sea.\n\n- Pressure points -\n\nChinese and American forces have had a series of close encounters in the disputed waterway that China claims almost entirely.\n\nAustin warned prior to Biden and Xi agreeing to resume military-to-military dialogue that accidents have the potential to spiral out of control, especially in the absence of open lines of communication between American and Chinese forces.\n\nFriday's meeting between Austin and Dong follows a phone call between the pair in April, and offers hope of further military talks to cool tensions.\n\nAustin's last significant interaction with a Chinese counterpart was in November 2022 when he met with Wei Fenghe in Cambodia.\n\nWei was subsequently replaced by Li Shangfu, who shook hands and spoke briefly with Austin at the Shangri-La Dialogue in 2023 but did not hold a formal meeting with him.\n\nAustin and Dong will give speeches this weekend at the Shangri-La Dialogue in which they are expected to touch on a range of their nations' pressure points.\n\nThe United States, increasingly worried about China's fast-developing military capabilities, has been strengthening its alliances and partnerships in the region to counter China's growing assertiveness over Taiwan and in the South China Sea.\n\nIn the meeting, Austin underscored the United States' commitment to the one China policy, but insisted that it would continue to \"fly, sail and operate\" wherever international law allowed, the Pentagon readout said.\n\nPhilippine President Ferdinand Marcos, who has sought to deepen defence cooperation with the United States as he stands up to Chinese actions in waters off the Southeast Asia country, will deliver the Shangri-La Dialogue's keynote speech on Friday.", "source": {"uri": "bssnews.net", "dataType": "news", "title": "Bangladesh Sangbad Sangstha (BSS)"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri":
